party_tutorial_dialog.title: Charming the Room
party_tutorial_dialog.body:
There are some guests in front of you. Say something to them!
Click on your remarks at the bottom of the screen, then click on the guests to use the remarks.
Try to match the subject of your remarks to their interests, shown in the markers beside them. If they like what you're about to say they'll highlight green and saying that remark will make their opinion of you go up. If they don't like that remark then they'll highlight red and their opinion of you will go down.
However, if their interest bar depletes, they'll get bored and their opinion of you will go down every turn until you speak to them again. Charm them all the Guests in a conversation, and make sure that nobody is bored in order to finish it. Just make sure you don't annoy anyone too much or you could run out of Confidence.
party_tutorial_end.title: Tutorial Complete!
party_tutorial_end.body: Felicitations! You have charmed the host of the Orphan's Feast! As the party winds to a close, you are free to engage any other guests, or make a discreet exit if you so desire. Just click the 'Leave the Party' button to exit the party and see how you did!
invitation_dialog.title: An Invitation Has Arrived!
invitation_dialog.body:
Madame, an invitation from $HOSTNAME of the $FACTION has arrived!

It says you've been invited to attend their $SIZE Party.

I've added the event to your Calendar.
style_change_dialog.title: Style Change!
style_change_dialog.body:
The $OLDSTYLE Style is now out of fashion and the $NEWSTYLE Style is now in fashion!
Adjust your wardrobe accordingly!
pay_day_dialog.title: It's Payday
pay_day_dialog.body:
It's time to pay the help. You're currently employing $NUMSERVANTS.
Their cost of employment this week is $TOTALWAGES.
This leaves you with £$LIVRE
fire_camille_dialog.title: Wait a minute...
fire_camille_dialog.body:
“Camille, what exactly do I pay you for?
“Oh Madame, why do you ask?
“No reason, just thinking about... budget stuff.
“Well Madame, I clean your house, do your laundry, cook your meals, sweep your chimney, manage the household, mend your clothes -”
“Fine! Fine! Forget I asked!”
cant_buy_dialog.title: Oh No!
cant_buy_dialog.body:
I'm sorry Madame, but you do not have enough space in your wardobe to fit this $ITEM.
At this time your Wardrobe can only hold $CAPACITY Outfits. Perhaps there is some way to expand your closet space?
cant_make_dialog.title: Oh No!
cant_make_dialog.body:
I'm sorry Madame, but you do not have enough space in your wardobe to fit a new Outfit. I can't create anything when you have no room to store it.
At this time your Wardrobe can only hold $CAPACITY Outfits. Perhaps there is some way to expand your closet space?
set_trend_dialog.title: Style Change!
set_trend_dialog.body:
You hear audible gasps as you exit your carriage. Your expertly coordinated Outfit, combined with your significant social stature, seems to have taken everyone aback. You can see the wheels turning in their minds as they rethink their stylings and choice of attire.
You have started a new fashion trend. The $OLDSTYLE Style is now out of fashion and 
the $NEWSTYLE Style is now in fashion!
reputation_wine_dialog.title: For you, Madame
reputation_wine_dialog.body:
Madame, thank you for joining us tonight. $HOSTNAME asked me to make sure you were taken care of when the Party began.
<Your Wineglass is now full>
refill_wine_dialog.title: Let's Top That Up
refill_wine_dialog.body:
Madame, I noticed you were running a little low on refreshment. As per $HOSTNAME's request, I'll check in occassional to make sure you have enough to drink.
<Your Wineglass is now full>
feature_incomplete_dialog.title: Pardon Our Dust!
feature_incomplete_dialog.body:
Sorry, that feature hasn't been completed yet, and is thus, unavailable.

Thank you for playing and thanks for your patience while we get the game completed!
sell_gossip_dialog.title: Are you sure, madame?
sell_gossip_dialog.body:
Are you sure you’d like to sell this $GOSSIPNAME for $GOSSIPPRICE?

If you do this, there should be $CAUGHTODDS chance of the public finding out.
peddle_influence_dialog.title: Are you sure, madame?
peddle_influence_dialog.body: This $GOSSIPNAME? For free? Merci beau coups madame! How would you like me to present this to my loyal readers? If you do this, there should be $CAUGHTODDS chance of the public finding out.
peddle_influence_dialog.increase_power: Increase the power of the $FACTION by $SHIFTAMOUNT
peddle_influence_dialog.decrease_power: Decrease the power of the $FACTION by $SHIFTAMOUNT
peddle_influence_dialog.increase_allegia: Push the $FACTION towards the Crown by $SHIFTAMOUNT
peddle_influence_dialog.decrease_allegia: Push the $FACTION towards the Revolution by $SHIFTAMOUNT
move_through_dialog.title: $ROOMNAME
move_through_dialog.body:
You've entered the $ROOMNAME.

Would you like to 'Work the Room' and engage the party goers in Conversation, or would you like to 'Move Through' and hope nobody notices you?
moved_through_dialog.title: Moved Through the $ROOMNAME!
moved_through_dialog.body:
You've succesfully moved through the $ROOMNAME unnoticed.
Now you can back to your real mission uninterrupted.
conversation_over_dialog.title: Conversation Over!
conversation_over_dialog.body:
The Conversation is over, you managed to Charm $NUMCHARMED Guests and $NUMPUTOFF Guests felt Put Off after speaking with you.

Your Reward for Clearing this Room is $REWARD.
charmed_host_dialog.title: Conversation Over!
charmed_host_dialog.body:
The Conversation is over, and you managed to Charm the Host!

Your Reward for Clearing this Room is $REWARD.
failed_host_dialog.title: Conversation Over!
failed_host_dialog.body:
The Conversation is over, but the Host was unfortunately Put Off by your behavior.

Your Reward for Clearing this Room is $REWARD.
out_of_confidence_dialog.title: Oh No!
out_of_confidence_dialog.body:
It appears that you ran out of Confidence during that Conversation. You just started stammering before suddenly leaving to 'Get Some Air'.

You've spent an hour here in the Vestibule collecting your wits but your sudden disappearance was considered quite rude.

You've lost $FACTIONREPUTATION Repuation with the $FACTION and $REPUTATION Reputation with society in general.
out_of_confidence_tutorial_dialog.title: Oh No!
out_of_confidence_tutorial_dialog.body:
It appears that you ran out of Confidence during that Conversation. You just started stammering before suddenly leaving to 'Get Some Air'.

You've spent a few moments here in the Vestibule collecting your wits but your sudden disappearance was considered quite rude.

Fortunately, the patrons at the Orphan's Feast are much more forgiving than the rest of the society. Give it another try!
missed_rsvp_dialog.title: Missed RSVP!
missed_rsvp_dialog.body:
You didn't RSVP to the $PARTYNAME.
The Host is rather upset with you and you've lost $REPUTATION Reputation.
caught_gossiping_dialog.title: Merde!
caught_gossiping_dialog.body: Madame, it appears that you've been found out. While 'Le Mecure' does its best to conceal our sources, some members of the $FACTION seem to have figured out that you were out supplier. This has damaged your Reputation both with them and with society in General.
caught_gossiping_third_estate_dialog.bod:
Madame, it appears that you've been found out. While 'Le Mecure' does its best to conceal our sources, some members of the $FACTION seem to have figured out that you were out supplier. This has damaged your Reputation both with them and with society in General.

Thankfully your contacts in the Third Estate have minimized the effects somewhat.
redeem_quest_dialog.title: Gossip? C'est Magnifique!
redeem_quest_dialog.body:
Thank you Madame, this is exactly the kind of sallacious trash our esteemed readers require!
We'll take care of your reward of $REWARD immediately.
rsvp_dialog.title: RSVP
rsvp_dialog.body:
You've been invited to a $PARTYSIZE Party being held by $HOSTNAME of the $FACTION.
$PROMPT
party_enemies:
It appears that some of your enemies will be in attendance:$ENEMYLIST
Would you still like to attend?
party_no_enemies:
It appears that none of your Enemies will be in attendance. Magnifique!
Would you like to attend?
rsvp_choice_dialog.title: Which Party?
rsvp_choice_dialog.body:
There are two parties being held on this day.
Which party are you interested in?
rsvp_cancel_dialog.title: Cancel Your RSVP?
rsvp_cancel_dialog.body:
You've already agreed to attend the $PARTYSIZE Party being held by $HOSTNAME of the $FACTION.
Cancelling will harm your reputation.
Would you like cancel?
rsvp_cancel_dayof_dialog:
The $PARTYSIZE Party being held by $HOSTNAME of the $FACTION is tonight!
Cancelling the day of will seriously harm your reputation.
Are you sure you want to cancel last minute like this?
no_outfit_dialog.title: You Have Nothing to Wear!
no_outfit_dialog.body:
Madame, it's not a figure of speech.
You literally have nothing to wear to this party. If we check in with the Merchant she might have something, but otherwise you may have to cancel.
out_of_money_dialog.title: Oh No!
out_of_money_dialog.body:
I'm sorry Madame, you appear to be completely out of money.

It looks like you'll have to borrow money from your various friends just to stay solvent.

This will cost you 20 Reputation but it will also get get you 200 Livres.
after_party_dialog.title: After Party Report
after_party_dialog.body:
The Party was hosted by the: <faction>
Your reputation changed by: <amount>
Did they like your outfit?
What was your RSVP bonus?
Big Event?
Novelty decay on your Outfit?
after_conversation_dialog.success.title: Félicitations!
after_conversation_dialog.success.body_c: You've managed to charm all of the guests!
out_of_money_and_rep_dialog.body:
I'm sorry Madame, you appear to be completely out of money.

Unfortunatley, it appears that you don't have enough Reputation to actually get the loans you'd need to continue.

I'm sorry Madamme, but I think this might be the end.
ambush_dialog.title: Ambushed!
ambush_dialog.body:
You've been Ambushed in the $ROOMNAME!
Prepare for Conversation!

conversation_intro.3: Oh, I've heard so much about you!
conversation_intro.4: You simply must meet my friends!
host_remark_intro.0: Have you enjoyed yourself so far?
host_remark_intro.1: What do you think of the new king?
host_remark_intro.2: Has the music been to your liking?
host_remark_intro.3: Have you seen latest opera yet?
host_remark_intro.4: Wherever did you get that dress?
reputation_text.1: Level 1: Pierre will approach you with special Gossip Requests
reputation_text.2: Level 2: You can get Reparte Bonuses in Conversations
reputation_text.3: Level 3: +5% Chance to Seduce a Party Host
reputation_text.4: Level 4: Your Remarks now a 25% stronger effect on your Enemies
reputation_text.5: Level 5: You now have 10% more time in Turns against a Host and to reply to their Remarks
reputation_text.6: Level 6: You're invited to all Decent Parties, regardless of Faction
reputation_text.7: Level 7: Another +5% Chance to Seduce Party Hosts (+10% Total)
reputation_text.8: Level 8: Attending a Party with a coordinated Outfit and Accessory may cause Fashion to shift your way
reputation_text.9: Level 9: You're invited to all Decent Parties, regardless of Faction
proceed_without_rsvp: You have unanswered invitations to parties tonight! Are you sure you want to skip them?
party.description.default: This party is being hosted by some dude or dudette. This segment will later have randomly generated Text describing the party. It should be pretty damn funny.
party.description.tutorial: The Orphan's Feast is a small social gathering spot for people of every class of society, though almost everyone who comes here does so alone.
party.intro.tutorial.body:
Bonjour Madame and Welcome to the Orphan's Feast!

You're alone? Don't worry! You'll find some of our other patrons in the next room.

In fact, we even have a some truly esteemed individuals here here tonight. They're getting drinks in the back room. You simply MUST talk to them before you leave!
party.intro.tutorial.title: Welcome!
party_crown_likes_and_dislikes: This party is being held by the Crown. They like outfits that are both luxurious and modest.
party_church_likes_and_dislikes: This party is being held by the Church. They like outfits that are both humble and modest.
party_military_likes_and_dislikes: This party is being held by the Military. They're a bit of a wildcard when it comes to outfits.
party_bourgeoisie_likes_and_dislikes: This party is being held by the Bourgeoisie. They like outfits that are both luxurious and revealing.
party_revolution_likes_and_dislikes: This party is being held by the Revolution. They like outfits that are both humble and revealing.
party_objectives:
• Your rival, Catherine Uzes, will be there
• Collect Gossip concerning the Church
• Speak with Ferdinand Foix
• Charm Mme. Agnes Taillefer III
party_invitation: Requests the attendance of $PLAYER to $PRONOUN $PARTY on $DATE. This $SIZE party is sure to be $FLUFF.
rsvp:
Skip this Party and you will suffer 
Backbiting: -50% to Seduction Chance
wardrobeTutorialStep: Click on a drawer to try on an outfit.
tutorial_go_step: Click here when you've found an outfit you like!
tutorial_intro_step:
This is the party map. You always enter parties via the vestibule.

Click on the lobby to go there.
tutorial_punchbowl_step:
Now that you've charmed the first room, let's move to the next one.

This room has wine in it, and will refill your glass whenever you enter it.
tutorial_host_step:
This room has some important guests in it.

If anyone knows where Armand is, it's them!
tutorial_remark_step: These are your remarks, click on one to select it.
tutorial_guest_step:
Click on a guest to say your remark to them.
Try matching this remark's subject with what one of the guests is talking about.
tutorial_leave_party_step:
Now that you've made an impression on the host,
you're free to leave whenever you want.
tutorial_lepetitmogul_selltab_step00:
I don’t just sell incredible outfits here, I also buy them! Right now, you’re looking at what I have in stock, but let’s see what you have first.
Select the selling button to look at your own outfits.
tutorial_lepetitmogul_outfitstats_step02:
Every outfit has four traits: modesty, luxury, novelty and style. Different factions prefer different looks.
For example, the Crown likes things that are luxurious and modest, but the Revolution prefers you look understated and racy. 
Dressing for the occasion make you more confident, and give you more remarks will give you more confidence at parties.
tutorial_lepetitmogul_outfitstyle_step03:
You should also make sure that your outfit is in style.
The popular style changes every week or so, so make sure that you stay current!
Having an in-style outfit will help you get new remarks faster at parties.
tutorial_lepetitmogul_buytab_step04: Now, let’s see what I have in stock!
tutorial_lepetitmogul_buyoutfit_step05:
Select one of my lovely outfits to see if it’s to your liking.
Remember my stock changes every day, so be sure to visit often!

stat.credibility.name: Credibility
stat.peril.name: Peril
crown1power: The Queen was recently seen bedecked in a spectacular new diamond necklace. Is it a sign of royal power, or unnecessary excess?
crown2power: A group of aristocrats have been trying to secure foreign sources of grain. Is it, as they claim, to distribute to starving farmers, or to hoard it for themselves?
crown3power: The Queen plans to grant a title to one of her closest female friends. Is the Queen recognizing merit or merely giving honors to her personal favorites?
revolution1power: A book salesman was recently arrested for printing profane criticism of the royal family. Is it punishment for vulgar slander, or repression of necessary criticism?
revolution2power: A trio of Third Estate delegates, in Paris for the Esates General, were detained by the Guet Royale. Were the Guet harassing honorable men, or forced to act against boorish provacateurs?
revolution3power: An aristocrat challenged a prominent revolutionary thinker to a duel of honor, who dismissed the challenge as barbaric. Is the thinker a enlightened man discarding old, unlawful traditions, or simply a coward?
bourgeoisie1power: A coalition of members of the Bourgeoisie have been investing large amount of money in hot air balloons. Are they visionaries, or just wasting money on ridiculous fancies?
bourgeoisie2power: A lawyer recently got in a fist fight with an aristocrat, who tried to claim his seat at the opera. Is this a sign of abuse by the nobility, or the lawyer's unnecessary impudence?
bourgeoisie3power: Some of the Paris's foremost industrialists have been trying to deregulate the price of bread. Is to allow bakers to have the money to make more bread, or is to profiteer off of hunger?
bourgeoisie1allegiance: Some representatives from the Third Estate have gotten free rooms to stay in from a prominent hotelier. However, they've been staying for a long time. Is this a sign of friendship, or are the representatives taking advantage of their host?
bourgeoisie2allegiance: A group of vinters are preparing a petition to reduce taxes on wine. Are they trying to make things affordable for the common man, or just increasing their profit margins?
bourgeoisie3allegiance: A wealth financier thinks the revolutionaries need to focus their efforts on drafting a constitution. Is he a pragmatic friend of the revolution, or a dismisive boor?
military1power: An older veteran, who stands accused of murder, has been discovered to be recieving care packages delivered by soldiers to his jail cell. Is this a sign of loyalty, or corruption?
military2power: A Captain in the Garde Royale was recently caught engaging in an utterly staggering number of extra-marital affairs. Is he a vulgar cad, or a romantic rogue?
military3power: There's been a sudden increase in soldiers taking second jobs throughout the city. Is this a dereliction of duty, or a sign that they need to be paid more?
military1allegiance: The King plans to weigh in on a legal case where an enlisted man struck an officer during an argument at a local theater. Is this attentiveness from the King, or an infringement on military discipline?
military2allegiance: They say that the King has been discussing changes to how the army pays its wages. Is the new pay schedule a necessary reform, or a way to pay troops even less?
military3allegiance: The King's ministers are begging him to supplement the army's presence around Paris with more foreign mercenaries. Is this meant to relieve exhausted troops, or is the nobility unsure of their loyalty?
church1power: A country priest, in Paris for the Estates General, has been granting asylum to accused criminals. Is he intervening on behalf of the people, or obstructing justice?
church2power: A bishop has recently intervened on behalf of a group of accused prostitutes. Is he protecting the virtue of innocent women, or trying to cover his own vices?
church3power: A group of priests are raising money to buy large parcels of farmland from destitute farmers. Is it an act of of relief or just expanding the Church's ownership of France?
church1allegiance: A bishop has called for the censorship an opera critical of the Church. The king has signalled his assent, but has taken weeks to make a pronouncement. Is the king taking the request seriously, or ignoring it?
church2allegiance: Representatives from the Third Estate have been calling on priests to rally in favor of land reforms. Is this a recognition of the Church's authority, or crude sabre rattling?
church3allegiance: The King has been sending personal representatives to Rome to negotiate with the Pope. Is he moving closer to the holy Father, or snubbing the clergy of France by ignoring them?

exhaustion_level_2: Exhaustion Level 2: Small credibility penalty at your next party or rendezvous.

exhaustion_level_4: Exhaustion Level 4: Large credibility penalty at your next party or rendezvous.
exhaustion_level_5: Exhaustion Level 5: Major credibility penalty at your next party or rendezvous.
well_rested: Well Rested: Small credibility bonus at your next party or rendezvous.

Yvette.name: Yvette Decaux
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Awaiting Insp:
Your index finger idly brushes along the top of her hand, and for the first time you notice something there, firm and unyielding.

Her wedding ring.
After a few minutes, you decide to head home, still trying to make sense of what just happened.
She walks away briskly, leaving you alone in the tavern.

Elisabeth stands up and gathers her things, hastily scribbling a note in her sketchbook. She tears out the paper and hands it to you. It's an address. 

"Write me a letter if you change your mind."

(Rendezvous with Elisabeth are now available)
After a few minutes, you decide to leave the tavern and head home, your mind still swimming with emotion.
With that, she walks away, stopping only to glance back one last time before she leaves you in the square.

As the crowd in the tavern starts to move on elsewhere, Elisabeth stands up and gathers her things. She stops to scribble a note in her sketchbook, then tears out the paper and hands it to you. It's an address. 

"Can you write me a letter, when you want to see me again?"

(Rendezvous with Elisabeth are now available)

However, none of these strangers notice. Without realizing it, they treat you and Elisabeth like any other pair of people in the world, and it's freeing. 

Like you've been holding your breath your entire life, and are finally able to exhale.

She slowly draws her hand away from yours, making a point to tap her wedding ring against your own engagement ring.

"Is it really that bad? There are a million kinds of love, but we only have one life. Does it feel right to spend it with only one person?"

You stay and chat a little while longer, commenting on the strangers at the nearby tables, and trying to determine who would be more interesting to draw. Your mind often wanders back to what any of these people would say if they knew what the two of you were doing together, just paces from them.
She notices your change in expression. "He... doesn't know, and I don't think he needs to."

Your index finger idly brushes along the top of her hand, and for the first time you notice something there, firm and unyielding.

Her wedding ring.

Not knowing what else to do, you look around the square to find some kind of distraction. Your wandering eyes catch a flash of sunlight glinting off of metal, and that's when you look down and notice it for the first time.

Elisabeth's wedding ring.

You squeeze her hand back, savoring your closeness together.

(You've gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
She squeezes your hand, slowly, tenderly.

Her voice is quiet, barely louder than a whisper. "I don't think I'm out of my slump just yet, but I'm still happy you're here."

(You've gained a little favor with Elisabeth)

After some time, Elisabeth's feverish drawing begins to subside. What started as a storm of lines and sketching winds down to a few careful marks as she works to get everything just so. Eventually she stops altogether and lays the sketchbook on her lap.

Her hand finds yours, and you both sit there for a while, and just watch the world go by together.

"Hmm, perhaps I can work with this." She says as she starts to unpack her supplies. 

Glancing with some uncertainty about the tavern she starts drawing, faster than you've ever seen anyone draw before. There's no hesitation in her movements, instead she sketches with the confidence that can only come from decades of practice.
"I've spent so much time worrying about people, but if I just draw their reflections in the water... all I have to do is focus on the shapes."

She starts drawing, faster than you've ever seen anyone draw before. There's no hesitation in her movements, instead she sketches with the confidence that can only come from decades of practice.

"Oh, that is good." She mumbles under her breath.

The two of you walk over to the fountain where you met Pierre, not that long ago. It's still as beautiful as you remembered it to be. The square has plenty of people in it, but it's not uncomfortably packed.

Elisabeth seem happy with it.

However, none of these strangers notice. Without realizing it, they treat you and Elisabeth like any other pair of people in the world, and it's freeing. 

Like you've been holding your breath your entire life, and are finally able to exhale.

Not knowing what else to do, you look around the square to find some kind of distraction. Your wandering eyes catch a flash of sunlight glinting off of metal, and that's when you look down and notice it for the first time.

Elisabeth's wedding ring.
She squeezes your hand, slowly, tenderly.
"I'm out her to find something interesting to draw. Any ideas?"
"What cheap romance did you pull that line from?"
"I can't even remember the last time I was excited by my own work."

With that, she walks away, stopping only to glance back one last time before she leaves you in the square. 

After a few minutes, you decide to head home, your mind still swimming with emotion.

As the sun starts to dip in the sky, Elisabeth stands up and gathers her things. She stops to scribble a note in her sketchbook, then tears out the paper and hands it to you. It's an address. 

"Can you write me a letter, when you want to see me again?"

(Rendezvous with Elisabeth are now available)

Elisabeth stands up and gathers her things, hastily scribbling a note in her sketchbook. She tears out the paper and hands it to you. It's an address. 

"Write me a letter if you change your mind."

(Rendezvous with Elisabeth are now available)
She walks away briskly, leaving you in the square. After a few minutes, you decide to head home, still trying to make sense of what just happened.

Her voice is quiet, barely louder than a whisper. "I don't think I'm out of my slump just yet, but this is the closest I've felt in a long time."

(You've gained a little favor with Elisabeth)

She slowly draws her hand away from yours, making a point to tap her wedding ring against your own engagement ring.

"Is it really that bad? There are a million kinds of love, but we only have one life. Does it feel right to spend it with only one person?"

You stay and chat a little while longer, commenting on passing strangers, and trying to determine who would be more interesting to draw. Your mind often wanders back to what any of these people would say if they knew what the two of you were doing together, just paces from them.
She notices your change in expression. "He... doesn't know, and I don't think he needs to."

You squeeze her hand back, savoring your closeness together.

(You've gained a little favor with Elisabeth)

After some time, Elisabeth's feverish drawing begins to subside. What started as a storm of lines and sketching winds down to a few careful marks as she works to get everything just so. Eventually she stops altogether and lays the sketchbook on her lap.

Her hand finds yours, and you both sit there for a while, and just watch the world go by together.

"I see what you mean, it is beautiful. Normally I focus on a single subject, but I haven't drawn a crowd in a very long time." She sits at the fountain's edge and starts to unpack her supplies. 

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
You stop in at a nearby tavern and take a seat. It's the middle of the day, but the crowd is closely packed.
She looks down at her bag, and shifts awkwardly. "I have plenty of willing subjects, and even commissions to complete, but none of it thrills me. None of it inspires me."

"Hmm, that could work..." she mumbles, more to herself than anyone else. 

"Let's go."
"Magnifique!" She says, clapping her hands together. "Let's go!"
"Do you have any suggestions? I need to practice."

"You're lucky that it's cute when you're the one saying it."

(You've gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
She gestures to her bag. A few sketchbooks, brushes, and other art supplies are poking out of the top.
"Fancy that, I'm doing the exact same thing"
"Oh, Yvette! What are you doing here?"
Then again, you've never seen a pigeon that still had all of its toes, so it can't be all that nice.
You pause to watch them, and wonder what it must be like to be content with something as simple as a handful of seeds. Is it a better life?
Just as you are about to turn around to find something more stimulating, you spot a familiar face.

While exploring the streets of Paris, you find yourself on a calmer street than most. The cacophony of the city fades away, and things are quiet, other than for the sound of a few pigeons feasting upon some grain that's been carelessly spilled in the road.
"Well, I don't think I can live with that."
"Of course he doesn't, this is just about us."

"There's a beautiful fountain that's not far from here. Would that work?"
"Why don't we stop into one of the taverns nearby? There might be something there."
"My ideas? I'd think the great Madame Le Brun would have more than enough subjects to draw."
"Why don't we stop into one of the taverns nearby? There might be something there."

"Exploring the city, looking for something interesting."
"Wandering the city, hoping I'd run into you?"
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Bearing Gifts: She holds the door open for you, and soon the two of you are whisked off to your destination.
She takes your stunned silence as agreement. "Good. I'm glad we understand each other."
"Oh, that is tempting..." She leans close to whisper in your ear. "...but I've already spent far too much effort to have the world miss out on how perfect I've made you look."
"If you don't want my gifts and you don't want to go out, you should have just canceled."
"However, I'm already here. So we are going out, and that's final."
(You have lost some favor with Madame Gazel)
She stares at you in tense silence.
(You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)
Her eyes drink in your every last detail. She wants your resistance, just so she can break it.
"Shall we go?"
Together, the two of you head outside, where René is awaiting you with Madame Gazel's carriage.
(You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)
(You have gained some favor with Madame Gazel)
"I didn't just dress up girls."
She laughs at the memory. "Of course, I had no idea why I was doing any of it back then, I just knew that I liked it."
Camille heads down to the kitchen, leaving you and Honorade alone.
"You're all set Madame!" Camille says with a curtsey. "Now, I must be going. The kitchen is an absolute mess."

You get dressed, as per usual, with Camille helping you into your outfit. It's a little odd at first, having Madame Gazel there, but once the three of you all start talking, you realize that you really enjoy having the company.
"Yvette, don't be ridiculous!" She laughs.
That warm whisper suddenly turns to ice. "So you will do exactly as I say, do you understand?"
"I thought so. After all, everyone needs to see how good I've made you look. Exactly how I like you."
"Shall we go?" She asks innocently, as if it was all in your imagination.
(You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazelle)

You look at yourself in the mirror, and you have to admit that Honorade has good taste. She spends some time adjusting your bodice, but before you know it, these adjustments slowly turn into something firmer, and more sensual. Yet, the moment you start to submit to her touch, she pulls away, leaving you wanting more.
Without another word Madame Gazel firmly, but politely, ushers Camille out of the room.
"But-"
(You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel)
(You have gained some favor with Madame Gazel)
"I liked being in control of all the details. I liked it even more when they fought back, but I still got my way."
Honorade continues her ministrations, but you can feel her slowing down. As you sit there, frozen in place, you wonder how one tells the difference between unwavering obedience and boredom.

Just as you start to pull away from her, she places her hands on your shoulders and forces you down into the at your vanity. Holding a makeup brush in one hand, she grasps you firmly by the chin with the other. "Protest all you want little Yvette. It won't do you any good. I always get my way, and you'll be no different."
"I'm glad you're grateful." She replies with a contented sigh. "I've always enjoyed dressing others up like this, even when I was child."
All that seems to matter is whether your appearance pleases her.
This is different. Being pulled this way and that. Being fussily primped and preened without any consultation to you whatsoever. You're not the one in control here.
However, those occasions were about comfort and efficiency. A ribbon tied here, a pin placed there. You were the one in control.
This, of course, isn't the first time anyone has helped you get dressed before.
"As I was saying, let's get you ready."
"That will not be necessary." Madame Gazel interrupts.
"Don't worry Madame!" Camille happily interjects. "That's something I-"

Honorade pulls a pocket watch from her bodice and notes the time, beofre putting it away. "It seems that I've already taken too much of your time. If we want to make it to our rendezvous tonight, you'll need some help getting ready."
(You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)
(You have been gifted Honorade's Outfit)
(You have been gifted Honorade's Outfit)
(You have gained some favor with Madame Gazel)
You set the parcel aside on your bed, for later.
(You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel)
You open the package to reveal a gorgeous black silk dress. Expensive, and rather revealing, it certainly feels in line with the bourgeoisie.
"Go ahead, open it."
"It's true, it was a very sweet attempt." Madame Gazel admits, reasuring Camille with a light pat on the cheek. Satisfied, she sets her focus on you.
"Madame you have to understand, I tried to stop her!" Camille wails softly.
Some moments later, they enter together, with Camille trailing behind Madame Gazel. Your hapless maid is carrying a large parcel with a bow on it.
Camille sets off to her new task with gusto, but you're not optimistic about her success, based on her stammered attempts at an argument in the stairway.
She barely conceals a smile. "I'd considered it, but this was really more of an unexpected bounty than anything else."
"I see. I had hoped for this to be a pleasant surprise."
"I had a feeling that you liked being spoiled."
"In fact, how would you feel about wearing it tonight?"
"I looked through my wardrobe and found that I had something which will look a lot better on you than it does on me."

The parcel is placed in your hands, and she continues "This morning, I realized that we're almost the same size. I also know that you, ever the social butterfly, are always looking for novel outfits to wear at parties."
"Bonsoir Yvette! I've come, bearing gifts."
A few moments later, Camille enters your room and whispers "Uh Madame... Madame Gazel is here to see you? Don't worry, I'll delay her until you're ready."
You hear knocking downstairs, at the front door. Camille answers it and you can hear an exachange, but the muttering is too soft for you to make out any specifics.
It's a few hours before your rendezvous with Madame Gazel, and you're in your room, just starting to get ready.
"Are you sure Madame Gazel? Perhaps we should just stay in..."
"Perhaps we just should stay in..."
"Do you always try to dress up girls in your clothes before you romance them, or am I just special?"
"Do you always dress up girls in your clothes before you romance them, or am I just special?"
"Yes, Madame Gazel."
<Stay silent, stay still, and let her do as she pleases>
<Smile> "Oh Madame Gazel, I don't think I should be letting you do this."
"Thank you for doing this."
"Are you sure that's the only reason you're in my room while I'm still half naked?"
"Ah, but I had something else in mind for tonight. I'd prefer to wait before trying that on."
"Well, I've never turned down a nice gift before, and I won't start now."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Coffee Run.as: Out of options, you part ways and head home. Things didn't work out today, but perhaps they'll go more smoothly tomorrow.
(You have spent 10 Livres)
Eventually, the day winds down and you head home. You're tired, but glad that things managed to work out.
"Thanks again for your help." Marguerite says to you for the umpteenth time as she passes you during one of your deliveries.

The cafe waitress shrugs. "Don't worry madame, I'll think of something." 

Her eyes don't portray the same optimism as her words.
(You have gained a decent amount of credibility)
Someone jokingly calls you two 'The Angels of Steam'. The nickname sticks, at least for the day.

You're not exactly sure how you get caught up in everything, but you're soon helping Marguerite ferry kettles of boiling water back and forth from the cafe for a few hours. It's exhausting, but you're met with a cheer from the patrons every time the two of you burst in the door with a new pair of kettles.
Someone in the crowd hurriedly escorts you into a tavern where they work. Immediately, Margueritte sets up her kettles on a roaring stove.
Perhaps there's something else that you can do...
(You have lost some credibility)

Your impassioned plea falls on deaf ears, as people in the crowd simply shuffle by. Admittedly, it is an odd situation, but you still curse the strangers for their inaction. It doesn't take long for you to notice that some of the people nearby have even grown suspicious of you.
Hearing your impassioned plea, someone in the crowd hurriedly escorts you into a tavern where they work. Immediately, Margueritte sets up her kettles on a roaring stove.
(You have gained a little credibility)
All the same, she smiles warmly to you "Thank you for trying. That's already more than anyone else here has done."
"The stove in the Cafe is broken and I have a lot of thirsty customers!"
It's amazing how indecisive everyone in the crowd was, until money entered the equation.
Some members of the crowd turn to listen as you make an impassioned plea for this poor working woman beset by misfortune. She needs no money, no supplies, merely a stove with which to heat her water!

She's happy to hear this until you start giving her directions. Her face falls and replies. "Non madame, I'm sorry but that won't work. You live too far away. The water will be cold by the time I reach the cafe. It has to be somewhere nearby!"

"Does anyone have a stove I can use? This is an emergency!" It's Margueritte, from the cafe! She's holding a bunch of kettles and looks absolutely frantic. 

Nobody is rushing to help, in fact they're trying to stay out of her way.
Behind you and to the right, you hear a commotion, you turn and spot a familiar face.

You are momentarily lost in a reverie imagining what life would be like if coffee tasted as good as it smelled. Would we ever drink anything else? 

It would be a jittery world, indeed.
Wandering around town, you realize that you're near Cafe Principe, but you can't smell the familiar scent of roasting coffee beans. Which is a quite a shame, because the scent is absolutely heavenly.
"I'm sorry Marguerite, I can't think of anything else."
<Give up>
"I will pay ten livres to the first person that lets us borrow their stove for the day!"
"Please! Can anyone let us use your stove? She needs it for work!"
"I will pay ten livres to the first person that lets us borrow their stove for the day!"
"Please! Can anyone let us use your stove? She needs it for work!"
"Marguerite, over here! Why don't you use the stove at my home?"
Assets/Collections/Incidents/A Lively Pl: With a shake of your head you turn and start the long walk home. The music fades into the distance and you welcome the hustle, bustle, and sophistication at the heart of Paris.
The entertainment may be on the coarse side for some, but it's perfect for those that just want to relax and have fun.
After a spending a few hours taking in the crowds and bobbing in time with the lively music, you decide to head home, but you have a feeling you'll be back there soon.
Sitting down at one of the rustic tables, you note down the guinguette in your journal. (Guinguette Paradis is now an available rendezvous location)
Turning a corner you stumble upon an idyllic looking establishment named 'Guinguette Paradis'. A band plays music, while the patrons drink wine and dance.
Passing through a checkpoint at the city's outer wall, you hear the sounds of music and raucous laughter.
Feeling like you could use some fresh air, you decide to take your travels to the edge of the Paris. As much as you like the city, the change of pace is appreciated.
"If I wanted drunk strangers and rustic music, then I would have stayed back in the village."
"Everyone here seems to be having a great time, and I can't blame them. This is a lot of fun."
Assets/Collections/Incidents/A Promenade: This is the perfect place to go with someone who wanted to get some fresh air, without the oppressing crowds of the city.
You head home immediately, taking a detour through some of the more lively parts of time in order to get your energy back up again. Hopefully, you won't have occassion to visit the gardens too often.
After lingering a few minutes further, you head home. Hopefully, you'll be able visit the gardens again soon.
Pulling out your journal, you jot down the location. (Jardin Des Plantes is now an available rendezvous location)

Looking around at the well manicured greenery, you realize that you've arrvied at the Jardin Des Plantes. It's beautiful and tranquil. A lush respite from the bustle and cacophany of the city. Couples stroll the paths, arm in arm. Furtive glances and nods of respect are exchanged between passing groups, as people put forth their best efforts to see and be seen.
Just as you cross the street, you spot a verdant clearing ahead of you.

Deciding to explore the 5th arrondisement today, you stroll along the southern banks of the river Seine. Barges sail up and down the river, jockeying for position with the pleasure crafts of the wealthy, and the ocassional floating bathhouse. A merry patron of one such bathhouse waves to you from the comfort of his tub.
"Walking in circles doesn't feel like my idea of a fun evening."
"It's nice to get a break from Paris sometimes."

Taking out your journal and a traveler’s pencil, you close your eyes and relax, just focusing on listening to the whole bustling cafe. Not focusing on one individual conversation, but just letting the sum total of the room flow into your ears, and then assessing it all together. Occasionally, you open your eyes to jot down a quick note.

She favors you with a quick curtsey before leaving. You sip at your drink and get settled in. It feels familiar in a way, like a louder and livelier version of ‘Le Cygne’, a tavern you used to frequent back home.

“Now, if you can excuse me madame, I must get back to my other tables.”
“After that? You head home with a little more energy, a little more knowledge, and hopefully you’re a little more well liked. That’s all there is, really!”

“Once you’ve listened for a while, you’ll probably get dragged into one of the debates. Be carefully with your answer, as news travels fast. Depending on who you support in the debate, you can earn some favor with one faction, and lose some reputation with another.”

“After you get your drink, you can settle in and listen to our patrons here. Everyone here is obsessed with politics, so it’s a great place to find out who among the high and mighty is doing particularly well at the moment. Everything is always shifting in Paris, so it’s nice to come in regularly and stay on top of things.”

“First you come in and sit down, and order something. While we can’t make you order anything, we would strongly prefer that you order some coffee.” She stops to stare at you significantly for a moment. 

“The coffee also perks you up, and makes you less exhausted, if you’re feeling tired. It’s no substitute for sleep, but it’s a start!”

“Oh, the cafe!” the woman exclaims, suddenly understanding your point. “Don’t worry, everything here is pretty simple, I’ve watched it play out with our patrons the same way everyday, for the last few years.”
“Is there anything else you’d like to know about?”
At the sound of fresh giggling from Monsieur Boehmer’s table she leans in close to you and whispers behind her hand “He’s not actually that funny, the laughing is just good for business.”
As for the women, they are... prostitutes.”
Instantly, the woman is all smiles, once again. “Oh yes, an excellent choice madame!”
With a scowl, she skulks away to attend to the other customers, while you applaud yourself for your thriftiness. She shortly returns with your water, which is surprisingly cool and refreshing.
“Is there anything else I can get you?”
“Oui, madame. I shall fetch you free water, while you occupy a table in our busy cafe.”
“If you insist, madame, I’ll leave you to your refreshments.”

Before you mix in anything, you decide to taste the coffee by itself. It’s bitter and acidic, but also full and potent. Very potent. You now understand why the customers are all so energetic.

(You have lost one level of exhaustion!)

She returns with your coffee, steaming and hot. The porcelain cup clinks lightly as she sets it down, along with containers of sugar and milk. 

“Enjoy, madame!” she says before curtseying again and leaving to attend to the other customers.

She gives you a quick curtsey before she checks in with another table, taking their order as well. You sigh deeply and take in the cafe around you. The whole place hums with excitement. Voices ebb and flow likes the waves of the ocean as patrons make new pronouncements and trade verbal barbs with their compatriots.

You gesture around the cafe as you ask the question, and the woman follows your gesture as it accidentally points towards a portly older man surrounded by a group of politely giggling young women. “Oh, that?” she asks. “That man is Monsieur Boehmer, he’s a regular.”

“Oh, certainly madame!” she replies happily.

(You have spent 3 Livres)
“What can I get you?”
“Bonjour madame, my name is Anne and let me be the first to welcome you to Cafe Principe!”
Finding a seat at an empty table, you’re approached by the woman from before.

Inside, the coffee house is packed with customers engaged in animate conversation and gesticulating wildly with cups of steaming coffee. Growing up, you were often told that religion and politics made for poor conversation, but it appears that none of these people got the same message.
Sensing the hostility in this rhetorical question, the students quickly dissipate. Satisfied, the woman in the apron heads back inside. With the doorway cleared, you happily enter Cafe Principe.

However, before you can give up on this venture, a woman in a coffee stained apron emerges from the door. She loudly asks if any of the students are actually interested in buying anything, or if they’re just hanging around to look important.

Eventually, you arrive at a bustling coffee house with large glass windows. The sign outside reads 'Cafe Principe'. Your heart sinks at the site of the massive crowd of students milling around outside the cafe. It doesn’t look like you’ll be able to get in at all.

Your nose picks up the scent of fine coffee and you find yourself subconsciously gravitating towards the origin of this delightful smell. The closer you get to the source of the scent, the thicker the crowds become.

Strolling through the 6th arrondissement, you weave your way through crowds of excited students, pontificating intellectuals, and agitated artists. It feels like every corner is home to another gallery, or part of the various academies strewn throughout the district.

Inside, you find a dining room brightly lit by crystal chandeliers, and furnished with mahogany tables draped in fine linen tablecloths. A few aristocrats look up from their table at you, and you suddenly feel rather underdressed in your day clothes.
Quickening your pace, you find a sign that reads 'La GrandeTaverne de Londres'. This is slightly puzzling, as it looks nothing like the rustic taverns you've seen elsewhere in France.

Just as you feel you've become used to the city's myriad smells, your nose manages to pick up a new, suprising scent. Flavorful, yet subtle. Layered, but restrained.

You've smelled good food before, but this is something else entirely.
Deciding to spend the day exploring Paris, your wanderings take you to the 12th arrondisement.
"I'm sure the food is good, but this is a little too stuffy for my tastes."
"Exquisite food and an elegant atmosphere. This is exactly what I was looking for."
Assets/Collections/Incidents/Frivolous F: This must be Parc Monceau, created by the fabulously wealthy Duke of Chartres. Taking note of your surroundings, you jot the location down in your journal. (Parc Monceau is now an available rendezvous location)

Turning on your heel, you head home. While you're not particularly enthralled by the gardens and the gaudy attractions therein, you wonder who you know that would possibly be interested in that sort of thing.
After a quick loop around the gardens, you head home. Already you're dreaming of excuse to head back, and trying to figure out who else you know that might appreciate Parc Monceau as much as you do.
It's fun and tacky, the kind of place to take someone that doesn't take themselves too seriously.

A massive garden, dotted with all sorts of fantastic buildings. Small Egyptian pyramids, Roman columns, Turkish tents, and more all cluster around a sparkling lake. People in costume strut about the different buildings, enthralling tourists with fantastic tales of dubious authenticity.

Still, it looks like everyone is having fun.
The sight that greets your eyes is nothing short of surreal.

Travelling the northern section of the 8th arrondisement, the sky is clear and the sun is shining. The crowds in this part of the city are picking up and, out of curiosity, you head in the same general direction.
"I don't think I could take too much of this for very long."
"This is absolutely ridiculous, and I can't wait to come back."
Assets/Collections/Incidents/Le Petit Mo: Her next words are a quiet mumble. “My mother gave it to me.”
“Oh… that…” her cheeks flush with embarrassment. “That’s lucky incense, I light it on slow business days.”

At those words, she looks giddy to the point of bursting, but tries to play it off as a knowing smile. This deception is only half-successful. 

“Oh, I think I can help with that.”
Her eyes light up. “Madame, you have come to the right place!”
“Bonjour Madame and welcome to Le Petit Mogol!” a woman, presumably the owner, calls out to you. “How may I help you?”
As soon as the door swings shut behind you, you hear a sudden rustling of fabric further in the store. “A customer? Hamdullah!” a surprisingly young voice calls out.

You open the door and walk into the tiny shop, which seems even smaller due to how absolutely full it is. This isn’t just a boutique, it’s a workshop for whoever works here. Rolls of gorgeous fabric cover every available surface. A cloying smoke hangs in the air. The scent is pleasant, but wholly unfamiliar.
“Le Petit Mogol” you mumble to yourself idly, trying to make sure you remember the name of the shop. Eventually, you find a small boutique tucked between some far grander buildings.

And now you’re here. Back home, they sigh and dream of places like this, then quietly get back to their little lives.

Not you. 

Your circumstances may be less than ideal, but you’re still here.

Paris may be a city swimming in fashion and finery, but this is the source. This street is home to all the major fashion houses in the country, and to Rose Bertin, personal dressmaker to the queen herself.

It’s a long walk to Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré, but the trek to the narrow street is worth it. Every block hums with a vibrant energy, bursting with life. Porters and social climbers wind their way through the streets, festooned with brightly colored parcels.

Assets/Collections/Incidents/That Most R:
Maintaining his look of indignity, he glances into his dripping wet snuff box.

“You take coins, right?”
“I suppose you could say that, yes. Our social pages are our most popular section, and we’re always looking for new material. Keep it believable, I’m not wasting my money on fabrications.”

You come upon a man in grubby finery, up to his knees in the fountain. His shoes have carefully been placed at the water’s edge. He does a little jig as he drops a wet coin into his snuff box, which is clutched tightly in his other hand.

Suddenly flush with embarrassment, he pauses to look into his snuff box.

“I do hope that coins are an acceptable form of payment...”
“Now what do you want?”

A devious smile crosses his face. 

“New to this, are you? Don’t worry, it’s much easier than you think.”
He raises an eyebrow conspiratorially and leans in closer to you. His breath smells like cheap brandy. “You are in luck Madame, because we are always willing to pay for such valuable… information.”
“How may I be of service?”

The stranger’s smile sours and he marches out of the fountain.

“I shall have you know, that fundraising is far more difficult than it appears. Even the most noble of men must occasionally stoop low to accomplish great things.”
His smile broadens and the man bows, his manner suddenly as elegant as the finest courtiers of Versailles. “Why, in fact I am, bonne damme! My name is Pierre Renaudot.
Noticing your presence, the main in the fountain turns to you with a nod and a smile that attempts to be ingratiating. “Bonjour madame.”
“Aha!” a reedy voice shouts triumphantly.

It’s at that moment you realize the splashing in the fountain is getting louder, accompanied by some of the most inventive profanity you’ve ever heard.

Against your better judgement, you decide to investigate.

“Office temporarily closed. Engaging in emergency fund raising efforts. We apologize for the inconvenience

- Management

PS: Fear not this setback, the light of journalism shall never fade!”
The door is locked, so you give it a knock. Nobody answers. Looking around, you find a hastily written note lodged in the door frame. It reads:

Suddenly, the alleys open up into a wider street near a square. You can hear the splashing of a fountain nearby. You finally find the sign for ‘La Trompette du Peuple’, the paint appears to be fresh, but the office seems awfully small.

You walk through the city, following Camille's directions. Eventually, you find yourself threading through narrower and narrower streets. The alleys, packed with refuse and the occasional vagrant napping in the shade, feel almost oppressive in their closeness.
“If I wanted to sell some gossip, how would that work?” <Tutorial>
“Are you still buying gossip?”
“If I wanted to sell some gossip, how would that work?” <Tutorial>
“I have some valuable… social information for sale”
“Are you serious? This is your emergency fundraising?”
“Are you Pierre, the esteemed editor of ‘La Trompette du Peuple’?”
Assets/Collections/Incidents/The Limits:
With the address noted down, you hurry home before the crowds start forming outside. You wonder if they'll ever figure out how to control that monkey.

Probably not.
This feels like the perfect place to visit with someone that loves to laugh. Someone that isn't afraid of liking things that are a little bawdy or lowbrow.

With the address noted down, you start the walk home, already eager to see one of their shows. Maybe they'll have figured out how to control the monkey by then.

Part of you hopes not.

When you finally tire of watching the monkey shreik at is handler and pelt them with scraps of fruit, you take out your pencil and journal to jot down the address of the theater. (Les Grands-Danseurs du Roi is now an available rendezvous location)

Out of sheer curiosity, you step inside. There isn't a production going on at the moment, but you see actors and carpenters rushing around to ready the theater for its next show tonight.

The frantic energy is only amplified by the sight of a hapless young man trying to corral a dancing monkey back into its cage. The monkey doesn't seem interested in cooperating.

Strolling down the wide, tree lined street, you finally find what you're looking for. Les Grands-Danseurs du Roi. It's the best known theater in the city, specializing two things: comedies, and skirting the absolute limits of good taste.
Today, you decide to explore the Boulevard du Temple between the 11th and 3rd arrondisments. It's the place in the city best known for its theaters.
"This just feels like vulgarity for the sake of it. I'd rather not."
"This is absolutely delightful. I can't wait to see it in full swing."
Assets/Collections/Incidents/The Rumour: The walk home is short and uneventful, much like your time at La Place Royale.
The walk home is short and uneventful, save for your daydreams of what secrets you may find in that place.
The socialites in the square are starting to filter out to their dinner appointments and other social commitments, and you decide to head home as well.

After you feel a little a more comfortable with how things work here, you stroll about the square. Staying on the absolute edge of conversations, you pretend to be a traveller just admiring the apartments and gardens.

It all feels so tense. Artisocrats and courtiers merrily flit from conversation to conversation with a practiced ease, but you can never lose the feeling that nobody has really let their guard down. Everything they do is a kind of public performance, reinforcing an image they're trying to create.
Stepping back, underneath a shady awning, you take some time to really take it all in.

After an hour or so, you manage to overhear something useful. Pierre will be very interested in this.

(You have acquired some new Gossip)
Staying on the absolute edge of conversations, you stroll about the square, pretending to be a traveller just admiring the apartments and gardens.
Everyone here is either well dressed, or dressed so casually that it only draws attention to how powerful they must be. After all, only the truly powerful can afford to downplay their importance.

Of course, without the benefit of a title or an introduction, you can’t approach any of these people directly. 

However, there’s nothing to stop you from overhearing things as you just ‘pass by’.
You see the elegantly dressed aristocrats strutting about the gardens, stopping briefly to chat in hushed tones.

La Place Royale, the favored social spot for all the aristocrats in the city. The hub of all gossip, social news, slander, and scandal. If there was ever a telling secret, or a salacious rumor, this was the place to find it.

Growing up, you read incessantly about Paris, devouring any book or map you could find. Yet for some reason you can’t remember what makes this area special, beyond nice homes and some buildings built in the 1300s…

Crossing between the 3rd and 4th arrondissements, you’re struck by the beauty of the buildings around you. Some of the oldest buildings in city are here, surrounded by the homes of wealthy aristocrats. The entrances of these elegant homes are blocked by garishly dressed doormen, who honestly look more bored than imposing.
"Well, that was dull. At least I got something valuable out of it."
"This could be a nice way to replenish my funds if things become difficult."
"Interesting, but I'd rather observe a little first."
"It's like being in a gold mine. Time to take my share..."

He dreamed of changing the country, and this was the political event of the century. You mailed love letters soaked in perfume, he replied with volumes about how much he missed you. The romance of it all helped make up for the inconvenience.

Though part of you is worried by your unfamiliar surroundings, you mostly feel excited. This place is to be the stage for your new life.

You crane your neck out the window to peer at Paris. It’s even more than you imagined. The streets are a riot of color and energy as people go about their days. Elegant persons of fashion strut like brilliant peacocks. Students stumble under the weight of their books. Beggars alternate between pleading for alms, and shouting invectives at passers-by. 

Everything feels significant, like world’s next act hinges on all of their choices.

(You have gained some favor with the Louis Antoine de Saint-Just)
(Youve gained a little credibility)
You nod to the more appreciative members of your audience before leaving towards your own carriage.
Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to a modest stranger.
Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to a mysterious stranger.
You consider the extravagant carriage for a moment, is this who you’d like to ride with?
Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to an honorable stranger.
You consider the bold carriage for a moment, is this who you’d like to ride with?
You consider the humble carriage for a moment, is this who you’d like to ride with?

The carriage to your right is richly decorated, yet somber. Swags of black crepe hang from the roof of the carriage, leaving only glimmers of the gold underneath. The decidedly feminine bent of the decorations indicates that the occupant is a woman, but all of the black suggests that she’s in mourning.

The carriage in front of you is obviously being used by a soldier of some sort. The driver is leaning intently towards the passenger compartment, waiting for orders. You recognize the insignia of the Queen’s Dragoons on the side of the carriage. It feels noble and proud, but also capable.

The carriage to the left of you is of foreign design, and features a gilded crest as its only ornamentation. This crest is emblazoned with a motto in latin, and appears to belong to a priest of some description. The curtains are drawn, but someone appears to have lit a lantern inside. Judging by the occupant’s silhouette, it looks like he’s reading.
However, there appear to be three other carriages waiting to leave, each of them quite different. Perhaps one of them can help?

Before you can even respond, he gets his carriage moving, leaving you alone with yet another indignity. 

Going back to Marcelle is obviously unacceptable, it’s too far to walk home, and most of the other guests have already left.

You check to make sure that you’re in the right place, but to no avail. The carriage you hired is simply not there. 

“He went home!” a passing coachman says helpfully, while adjusting the harness on a particularly grumpy horse. “Doorman came out about an hour ago, and told him you wanted the coach to leave without you. Seemed real important, so he went home.”

Scanning the faces of your new audience, you see the glaring, unamused faces of the various party guests. Your views on Marcelle, and the Crown in general, have not gone unnoticed. The coachmen and valets on the other hand, think you’re hilarious.

When you arrive at the place where your carriage is parked, you quickly find out that… it isn’t. 

It’s gone.

When you finally get to the door, you feel a brutish shove, and you stumble out into the courtyard, barely keeping your balance in your heels. The area is equally crowded, with various persons entering their personal carriages. 

You can hear somebody snicker, but you have no idea who it was.

Boiling over with anger, you turn and rain insults upon the house, upon the host, even upon her dog. In fact, you consider throwing your shoe through one of their windows, before you remember how much you like that shoe. 

It’s then that you notice that several of the carriages have stopped, just to watch your display.

Choosing to take the high ground, you straighten your posture and hold your head high, striding towards your carriage as if it was your intention to leave like this all along. While you make a great effort to haughtily avoid eye contact with all of those watching you, you can tell that some of them are quite surprised by your decorum in this dire situation.
The only thing left to do is go home.

Before you can reply, a valet grabs you roughly by the arm and drags you from the room. People like Viscountess de Foix don’t need to do their own dirty work, they have servants for that. It takes far longer than you’d like to get outside, as the entryway is crowded with guests preparing to leave.
 
You can feel their eyes weighing heavily on you.
“A priest should be willing to help a poor, innocent woman like myself. Let’s go.”
“Perhaps not, I’ll examine the other carriages.”
“A wealthy widow helping a lost soul in need? It works in the books. Let’s go.”
“Perhaps not, I’ll examine the other carriages.”
“He’s a man of honor, sworn to protect France. I’m the next best thing to that. Let’s go.”
“Perhaps not, I’ll examine the other carriages.”
<Inspect the extravagant carriage to the right>
<Inspect the bold carriage in the middle>
<Inspect the humble carriage to the left>
“That’s fine by me! My face was the only pretty thing in that gaudy house anyway!”
*Sigh* “This has been a night. I’ll just leave.”
Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Lovesick Pr: He turns on his heel and leaves as quickly as he came. Father Sidotti stares at the doorway in stunned silence.
"Ah there you are, Father Sidotti! I thought you had gotten lost. This building is rather poorly designed, you see."

At that moment, a dour and unsatisfied looking man enters the room, his brow knit in a permanent furrow.

"I stand corrected." Father Sidotti mumbles to you.
Your brow furrowed in concern, you take a moment to compose yourself before you leave the now abandoned room to explore your other opportunities at the party.

"You... you actually got rid of him. That was amazing." He says, astonished.

(You have gained some favor with Ludovico)

Finally, they finish up, and the interviewee departs.

"I'm sorry for that madame, his words were completely uncalled for. Unfortunately, I'm not really in a position to start scolding important contributors, no matter how boorish they are."

Your stomach churns at the thought of doing anything this man tells you to do, but you step away from the conversation and let the two of them finish their interview. Father Sidotti spends the entire time looking like he's handling a viper by the tail. Thankfully, Monsieur Bellande seems too interested in himself to notice.
He leaves, grumbling something about 'feminine inconstancy' or the like.

"However." He whispers. "One must remember that, in this city, even the walls have ears." 

You hear the footsteps of a servant going by, and wonder if you're proclamation will reach the ears of your various enemies. It seems likely.

"Madame, I can safely assure you that he is." He states, eyes focused on something distant and terrible. "The man spent thirty minutes complaining about music. Not a particular kind, he complained about the entire concept of music!"

"... but he's awful! I've never met a man so determined to see the worst in everything."

"Recently my superiors in Rome assigned me to interview one 'Monsieur Bellande'. We're trying to form a complete picture of the situation in France. Tonight, I've tried to speak with him..."

He flushes with embarassment for a moment before turning his head from you and pouting. "I don't have to justify this! Everyone has their way of dealing with the world's slings and arrows, this one is mine."
"It's just that my recent assignment has been rather... unbearable."

"Please let me introduce myself, I am Father Sidotti." He says with a polite nod of his head.
He closes the book and tucks it under his arm. "Don't trouble yourself with that madame. This is from my own collection."

He glances down at the book and blushes. "It's been fun so far. I loved the escape from the nunnery."

(You have gained a little favor with Father Sidotti)
He notices your wandering eyes "My French is still rusty. This one was an easier read than the others..."

You try to keep your facial expression neutral when you recognize the book, ' L'Histoire Extrêmement Vraie de Julie d'Aubigny'. It's a romance, the tawdry kind, filled with rebellious and wanton women. Certainly a fun read, but not what you were expecting.
"Let me introduce myself, I am Father Sidotti. I beg your pardon, Madame Yvette I swear I'm normally more social."
The book is bound is faded red leather, and while it's well read, doesn't appear to be a bible.
He smiles and tucks the book under his arm. "Oh, if only the reasons were that exciting. Unfortunately, no beguiling person of mystery like yourself, just an avid reader."
"It's quite alright, Yvette." He replies, straightening out his cassock, and generally recomposing himself. "I shouldn't have let myself get so lost in my book."
"I'm so sorry madame, you just startled me. Who are you? Are you alright?"
Suddenly noticing you, he leaps up with a shout "Figlio di puttana!" You know that wasn't French, and you're fairly certain it wasn't polite.
Slowly and carefully, you check behind the door. That's where you find a priest reading a book.

"You actually got rid of him... that's amazing." Ludovico says with an enormous grin. "I mean, I'll still have to interview him later, but it's important to enjoy the little miracles."

“And what has brought you to this bustling metropolis?”

“Seeking the finer things in life? Well, you’re in the right place for it. Fashion is a way of life here."  He gestures around the tavern and you can see that even the people of more humble means have chosen their attire carefully.
"Ambition, advancement, and glory? Such things are not easy for a commoner like yourself. However, you are correct, Paris is the place best for those looking to raise their station."

"You've travelled all the way here for your fiance? Such love and devotion remind me of when I was your age." His eyes have a far off look for a moment. 

"Never let yourself lose sight of such things."
“Et vous, madame? What has brought you to Paris, so far from home?”

“But of course, the harvest has not been so good this year, which is what brings me to Paris. I’m searching for a way to revitalize our estate. Back home, I tried new farming techniques, imported tools, and I even built a shrine to Saint Isidore himself! Yet, it was to no avail. So I am here, in search of a solution.”
"The Baron de Marbo?" He pauses to think, scratching his chin. "Why does that name sound so familiar?"
“Well, madame you are in luck, for you have arrived in the most significant city in all the world.”
“Do not worry madame, I’m sure you’ll be able to return there soon enough!” He replies with a warm laugh. “I myself came a few months ago from similar, idyllic surroundings in Brittany.”
“Where did you journey from?”
“Ah, bonjour madame! You must have just arrived in Paris as well.” He says affably.

You approach a woman who’s standing by herself. She’s looking around at the party, and just seems extremely pleased to be here.

“Isn’t this magnificent?” She beams. “So many revolutionary minds in one place, all brought together by one man.”
“So, he’s a political hobbyist, who advances himself by condemning others? Did I get that right?”

“Perhaps later on, you’ll be able to put in a good word for me?”

“However, with her current level of favor at court, any suitor would have to be influential indeed in order to attract her notice. She also happens to be rather particular about her appearance, and in all my years of knowing her, I have yet to see her forget anyone who has slighted her.”

That familiar smile is suddenly back in place. "Thank you for joining me on this little stop! I think I'm ready to do what I actually promised to do, and walk you home. Sorry again for boring you with all of that."
With a great swig his finishes off his wine and drops some coins on the counter. You finish off yours as well, but in a more refined fashion.
"I suppose that's true." He admits. He stares at the lamp on your table, considering your point.
"And vive la roi to you as well!" He laughs with a mock salute. "I didn't expect you to be such a commited monarchist. Still, you're absolutely right."
"With an endorsement like that, how can I say no?" He laughs. "I must admit, I never took you for such a firebrand."
"I suppose it's true that I was born to a noble title." He admits. He stares at the lamp on your table, considering your point.
(The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Revolution somewhat)
Alexandre sighs and shakes his head. "Je suis désolé. That was all a little more serious than I'd intended."
(The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Crown somewhat)
"You know what? You're absolutley right. All over Paris, commoners cry out for freedom. Me, and my compatriots should be the ones to give it to them."
"Merci, Yvette. It's nice to know that someone like you has confidence in me."
"You know what? You're absolutley right. I have a duty to defend my birthright, if not for myself, but for any children that I should have."
"I was so confident that I'd prove him wrong. That I'd take all the things he'd given me and make him proud, even as a simple soldier."
"Then... he died less than a fortnight later. I never claimed his title."
"So, I enlisted. Father wasn't happy, but I didn't it anyway. At his insistence I did so under a different name, so as not to bring shame upon our legacy. To not bring shame upon him."
As he sips his drink, you catch a glimmer of something in his eyes. Was that doubt?
"These days, I feel closer to the common people's struggle for freedom."
"I just don't know."
"These days, I feel closer to the Crown. I'm a child of nobility, shouldn't I serve that tradition?"
"Now, I look at everything happening the city, I and don't know how to feel. Am I even a real noble? Or am I just a commoner whose had more advantages than most?"

He pauses to examine his hand in the candlelight, as if his skin could answer some long, unanswered mystery. "Of course, it happens that men like me need four generations of documentation to prove their link to nobility, something we didn't have."
"I'm not sure if I told you this, but what spurred me to enlist was that I wanted to show my father that I was a good as any other noble."
"However, to answer your question, yes. As his eldest legitimate son, I'm the heir to his land and titles, should I choose to claim them... from his wife."
"The only thing that's wrong are the laws that let people be bought and sold at all."
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
"Don't worry, it was only a few months before he bought me back, and brought me here. The second I set foot on French soil, I was a free man."
"He needed money to pay for his return to France, and claim his fortune and title. That's why he sold me, to pay for the trip over."
"So yes, it just was a temporary inconvenience."
"Once I arrived, he hired tutors to make up for lost time in my education. I learned how to fence, how to ride, even how to play an instrument. All of the things that make one a proper gentleman."
"In the eyes of the law, I was always a nobleman, even when I was a slave."
"What? Absolutely not! He did what he could to help me."
"I'm glad you liked it!" He laughs, clinking glasses with you.
"Once my father got his fortune, he bought me back."

"Once his parents died, he could come out of hiding and claim his inheritance. But first, he needed to get to France to prove his legitimacy. So, he temporarily sold me to pay for passage on a ship, so he could claim his title."
"My father owned my mother, so I was born his slave."
"Let's say that he had a falling out with his brothers that lasted a few... decades."
"Because you can still sell slaves in the colonies, and I was one." He says, like it's the most obvious thing imaginable.
"Well, he was forced to it," Alexandre explains. "Even though he was the eldest son, and the heirs to our fortune, everyone in the family thought my father was dead."
"Exactly!" He replies excitedly, almost grateful for your agreement.
"So my father sold me. Well, technically, he pawned me off..."
"Of course, to get that pleasure for himself, he first had to get us from his hiding place in Saint-Domingue to the the family estate in France." Alexandre punctuates this with a long sip of wine.

"He didn't disapprove at all, in fact he delighted in my adventures. Sometimes, I think he was trying to live through me."
"As fun as it sounds, I was just another jobless scion of nobility, living off of my father's largess."
"He'd lived a nobleman's life of ease, and he wanted the same for me. To be honest, I was more than happy to take him up on his offer."

"When I first moved to Paris, I spent years as a typical, unscrupulous rake. Strutting about the Palais-Royale, finding romance in the booths of Nicolet's theater, spending far too much money on fine clothes and finer drink."
"Oh, the usual. Wine... women... other people's money."
"Me? You flatter me." He chuckles. "You should have seen me a few years ago."
"If that's the case, maybe we should have met a few years ago." He smirks as he takes another sip.
"Then again, he often went to great lengths to obtain his pleasures."
"Malaga was always a favorite of my father. Even when I was growing up in Saint Doaminue, he would leap at any chance to get a bottle of it."
Alexandre pauses to contemplate the charms of his glass of Malaga by the light of your table's lamp. His eyes seem focused on something distant.
You clink glasses with him, and sip the fortified wine. It's sweet, and strong. The chill inside you melts away, almost instantly.
Raising his glass for a toast, he says "To quick decisions and life's little joys."
Stopping at the tavern's entrance, he holds the door open for you. "After you then, madame."
Both of the drinks arrive and he fills your glasses before his own.
Alexandre orders a bottle of Malaga from the barmaid. You ask for a pitcher of water to accompany it. If one isn't careful, the hangover from these sweet wines can be absolutely debilitating.

Stopping at the entrance, he holds the door for you. You sigh, and hope this doesn't drag on for too long.
Inside, the tavern is small, but cozy instead of cramped. You can feel the heat from the fires in the kitchen, and a young man atop a small stage is tuning his violin.

"Would you care to join me?"

"Merci, Yvette. It's nice to know that someone like you has confidence in me."
Alexandre is once again walking you back home after your rendezvous. It's unusually chilly tonight, so you both walk close together, arm in arm, to help stave off the cold.
"Merci Alexandre, I appreciate your restraint."
"Don't sell yourself short, this has been great. I appreciate you trusting me like this."
"Trust your gut."
"Trust your gut."
"It sounds like you already have your answer. Trust your heart."
"Trust your gut."
"It sounds like you already have your answer. Trust your heart."
