"I've never met someone better prepared to fight for the common good. Support the Revolution."
"Trust your heart, you're a child of both places."
"You were born a noble and nothing changes that. The Crown needs you."
It's still an amazing story.
It's still an amazing story.
"Does this mean you're actually a nobleman?"
"Alex, your father sold you like property. That's monstrous."
"Temporary or not, it's still an amazing story."
"Does this mean you're actually a nobleman?"
"Alex, your father sold you like property. That's monstrous."
"I have to say, that's an amazing story."
"I'm sorry, he... uh... sold you? How? Why?"
"How could your father do that to you?"
"Well, at least you got to France."
"And what pleasures were those?"
"What pleasures were those?"
"You exercise a lot more restraint"

Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Wealthy Wid: "Do you understand me?"
"And I think that any relationship we have moving forward, would be more pleasurable if you referred to me by that title."
She examines you carefully before continuing. "Because any relationship with another is about more than who they are. It's also about who that other sees you as."
"I hope to see you again soon."
"Think nothing of it, then." she says, staring into her glass. "It was a mere, passing fancy."
"Merveilleuse" she replies. "Thank you for indulging me, Yvette."
"I think that I'd prefer for you to call me 'Madame Gazel', from now on. Could you do that for me?"
"When we first met, I introduced myself as Honorade." She says with a devilish smile.
"Before I go, would you mind doing me a favor?"
Eventually she notices him. "Ah, that's my servant René. I'm sorry Yvette, but I'm needed elsewhere."
You find yourself feeling pleased, but otherwise unphased by the encounter. After a few moments collecting your thoughts, you move on to the rest of the party.
You take a moment to get your bearings, before you move on to the rest of the party. All the same, you can't quite get this woman out of your head.
Then, in a dramatic swirl of black tafetta, she turns and leaves.
"Perhaps I'll see you again."
"Ah, that's my servant René. I'm sorry Yvette, but I'm needed elsewhere."
Out of the corner of your eye you notice a man in the livery of a servant, wearing a small black armband trying to politely get Honorade's attention.

Out of the corner of your eye you notice a man in the livery of a servant, wearing a small black armband, trying to politely get Honorade's attention. He seems to be having quite a difficult time pulling her attention away from you.
The two of you continue to chat together for a while, but eventually the conversation peters out on its own.
The conversation continues for quite a while. It's delightful, romantic and edgy. It's almost theatrical in its over the top-ness, but you get the feeling that's just how Honorade is.

"However, I would caution against putting too much faith in the trappings of a good life. No amount of trappings will ever make the heart of something whole, but that's up to you to discover for yourself."
(You have gained a little favor with Honorade)
"Far too many people are caught up in a world of numbers, theories, and treatises. All the grandest ideas in the world mean nothing without a life well lived."
(You have gained some favor with Honorade)
(You have lost a little favor with Honorade)
"All you'll have is the consequences of your retreat, whatever they may be. That's no way to live at all."
"Really? How unfortunate," she sighs. "If you let yourself be driven by an aversion to something, you'll never get what you really want."
"Ah, you are a woman after my own heart. A love of feeling is such a rare trait in this so called 'age of reason'."

"An ambitious one are we? I can appreciate that sentiment. There is certainly some allure to the finer things in life." She rplies, running the back of her hand against the sumptuous taffeta of her dress.
"What are your passions, Yvette? What drives you?"
"However, obligations are tiresome conversation. I'd rather speak of passion."
"Of course, that's no longer possible, but we all have our obligations." She sighs and sips her water.

"I like your adventurousness, but be careful. It might get you hurt."
"Of course, I can't blame the other guests for not speaking with me. After all, most of them have never seen me before."
(You have lost a little favor with Honorade)

She looks you up and down. "Judging from you appearance and the latest rumors, I can safely assume you are the infamous Yvette Decaux, non?"
"Walked directly into the spider's web, have we?" She says with a wicked smile.
Her laughter is quiet and deliberate. "I do have a tendency to do that, don't I?"

"My name is Honorade Gazel, but you may simply call me Honorade."
She looks you up and down. "Judging from you appearance and the latest rumors, I can safely assume you are the infamous Yvette Decaux, non?"

"I'd rather prefer if you actually answered my questions first. Be that as it may, I am Honorade Gazel. Just another person attending this party."

She cuts you off right as you're about to introduce yourself. "And who might you be?"

However, just as you start walking towards her, she stares at you with a surprising intensity, like she's studying you. Feeling a little unnerved, you're starting to understand where all of this intimidation business is coming from, but you can't stop now.
You shrug and take a healthy sip of wine. After all, this all sounds to you like an absolutely perfect reason to go talk to someone.
You scrutinize the other guests, their darting glances and concealed whispers. Someone attempts to approach her, but suddenly thinks better of it. Are they intimidated by her?

An elegant woman in black is standing off to the side of the party by herself. Her presence is obvious and while nothing about her seems outwardly wrong, you can see that the other guests are making an effort to avoid her.
You're taking a moment to yourself, listening to the party's exquisite string quartet, when you notice something odd.
"I don't think I'm comfortable with seeing you that way, Honorade."
"Yes, I do. Madame Gazel."
"Why, exactly?"
"I don't think I'm comfortable with that."
"Yes, Madame Gazel."
"Interesting, but I don't know yet what to make of her."
"That was far more... intriguing than I expected. Hopefully I'll be able to see more of her."
"To be honest, I'm just here because I wanted to get away from home."
"Passion itself is what drives me. I want excitement. I want to feel."
"I want what I deserve, and I'll do anything to get it."
"What do you mean, no longer possible?"
"The other guests are afraid of you. I found that intriguing, and wanted to learn why."
"You stood out from the crowd, I found it intriguing."
"I was growing bored too, and was hoping you could fix that."
"Just another party guest who's wondering why you're all alone."
"I'd rather know who you were first."
"My name is Yvette Decaux, madame."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Surprising: After the woman leaves, you question a few more of the guests, but none of them seem willing to talk about Armand.
There’s no sign of him, not even an open tab with the tavernkeep.
With the woman gone, you question a few more of the guests, but to no avail. None of them seem willing to talk about about Armand.

After a long pause, she continues “Tread carefully. Talents like yours are most valuable, and valuable things tend to attract danger.” The voice of another guest calls out behind her, and she quickly excuses herself before disappearing into the crowd.
“I’m sorry, but I don’t think I can help you find your Armand.”

The woman barks out a laugh of genuine surprise. “If this is what you do for fun, I can’t wait to see what you do when you’re being serious.” She pauses to sip at her wine again, finding her glass to be empty. “I’m sure I’ll see you around,” she says, before slipping into the crowd.
“I get the feeling that you’re going to fit in here just fine,” she remarks with the faintest hint of bitterness before disappearing into the crowd.
A look of shock ripples across her face for a brief moment, before return to polite neutrality “Ah, I see.”
“What are you doing here, really?”
“So, let me be more specific. What are you trying to do here, Madame Decaux?”

“You just walked in, swept an entire room of strangers off of its feet, and made it look easy. Not only that, you did it without a single one us managing to learn anything about you. I know your name, and nothing more.”

“Yes, you said that,” the woman observes idly. She sips her wine again, examining you. “I’m just having a hard time figuring you out. You’re obviously a girl fresh from the countryside, but you do not conduct yourself like one… at all.”
She sips her wine, patiently. Intently.

You feel a tap at your elbow and turn around, finding yourself face to face with a woman from one of your previous conversations.

“Who are you? I mean, who are you really?” she asks.
The conversation finishes as all the others had, with the various guests walking away from you, charmed and satisfied. A few days spent cooped up in a carriage have done nothing to dull your skills.
"Me? I'm just having fun."
"Me? I'm just having fun."
"I just moved here, so I'm trying to get a feel for Paris."
"I just moved here, so I'm trying to get a feel for Paris."
"I'm trying to find my fiance, Baron Armand de Marbo."
"I'm trying to find my fiance, Baron Armand de Marbo."
"Pardon moi, I'm not sure I understand the question."

Assets/Resources/Incidents/A Young Fireb: Everything seems that way with him. Larger than life heroes, in a perpetual clash against evil. Great people sacrificing themselves for the weak.

He leaves as quickly as he came, already striding over to the guests in the other group.
The two of you chat a while longer. While his main interests are political, you find that he knows a surprising amount about poetry and theater, especially when it comes to legends and heroic epics.

You spend the next few minutes walking around the party, wondering what to do next. Yet, your thoughts keep coming back to that distressing young man. There's something dark inside of him, you're certain of it.
You spend the next few minutes walking around the party, wondering what to do next. Yet, your thoughts keep coming back to that fiery, beautiful man.

(You have gained a little favor with Antoine)

However, you quickly run out of things to say, and Antoine takes the time to glance over his shoulder. He notices that some other guests of the party are waiting patiently for him. "It appears I am needed elsewhere, madame. I must go."
Antoine glances over his shoulder and notices that some other guests of the party are impatiently waiting for him. "It appears I am needed elsewhere, madame."

The two of you chat a little longer. While his mind is often focused on politics, his zeal manages to stop it from becoming tiresome. In some ways, you see quite a bit of Armand in him.

Of course, Armand's passion seems far less violent, so that's something to consider.
(You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
(You have lost a little favor with Antoine)

He smiles, caught a little off guard. "Well, I did study oratory in school, until I found my teachers wanting."
He grunts dismissively. "The old order must be cast aside as soon as possible, lest we allow more people to become victim to its repression and cruelty."
"Oh, that I can guarantee." He replies. His gaze is unflinching, but he can't help but smile.
"Will we stay and be incinerated, or develop the courage to jump into the waters below?"
(You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
(You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
"Right now, the people of France stand at the edge of a cliff, a raging forest fire burning at our backs."
(You have gained some favor with Antoine)
"The rest of us cannot afford such a privelege."
He looks into the distance and sneers. "You sound just like them. France's future matters for all of us. We cannot afford to be polite with what's at stake."
You follow up your statement by demurely batting your eyelashes at him. He doesn't seem to notice, instead nodding along thoughtfully. "Humility is a virtue. I respect that."

"That's exactly it!" He growls. "Politics is not some civil debate where, at the end, everyone gets to simply agree to disagree. It is real decisions, with real consequences, for real people! The nobility can pretend to sit above it all because they're isolated from those consequences."
"They don't want me involved with the Revolutionaries. They don't understand the importance of our times."
"Of course, as much as I love the character and the people of the countryside, it's probably for the best that I'm here. My relationship with my family has been rather... strained, as of late."
(You have gained some favor with Louis Antoine de Saint-Just)
He leans back and reappraises you, a smile forming on his lips. "Oh really? Your caution is wise. One can never be too careful."

(You have lost a little favor with Antoine)

"I can tell from your accent that you're not from around Paris either. I'm only in the city for a few months from Blérancourt. Someone invited me here, and I'm using the opportunity to try to get one of my plays published."

"However, I've already heard of your escapades, and I don't think I've like what I've heard."
"Thankfully, I've already heard of your exploits, and I must admit that I like what I've heard."
Pausing to breathe deeply, his expression visibly softens. "My apologies. With everything that's going on, there's always the concern of the Crown putting spies in our midst."
"But please just call me Antoine. I would rather not share my name with tyrants."
He eschews the customary bow for a quick upward nod of respect. "My name is Louis Antoine de Sant-Just."
"Well Madame Decaux, we already have enough people in our midst who are 'just observing'. What this country needs is action."
"Well, it's nice to have you with us, Madame Decaux. Welcome to our meeting of the minds."
"Who are you, and what exactly are you doing here?"
Suddenly, you notice a young man heading straight towards you throug hthe crowds. Frankly, he's beautiful, but he radiates a dangerous intensity.
Right now, however, you're simply content to watch events unfold from afar.

Keeping a distance from the crowds, you examine the attendees of this so called 'Revolutionary Salon'. All in all, they seem quite the ecclectic bunch, a mix of stern scholars, opinionated lawyers, and outrageous bohemians. The mood is both tense and energetic.
"Well, that was utterly terrifying."
"Well, that was utterly terrifying."
"Well, that was utterly terrifying."
"Well, that was utterly terrifying."
"Well, that was utterly terrifying."
"Well, that was utterly terrifying."
"Zeal, passion, and energy. He's certainly not boring."
"That's quite a line. Have you been practicing it?"
"If our homes are being incinerated, then I'd wish to stay and save them."
"It all depends, are you diving with me?"
"Are you sure? Politics isn't for everyone, after all."
"I don't know much about any of that, but I'd love to to learn."
"Then they're fools. The writing is on the walls, everywhere you go. We must care or die."
"I'll answer that once I know who I'm dealing with. Who are you?"
"I'm Yvette Decaux and I'm just observing, nothing more, nothing less."
"My name is Yvette Decaux, and I'm just woman who's excited by revolutionary ideals."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Alexandre's L: Using your map, it doesn’t take long to figure out where this particular fountain is. In fact, you could visit it today if you like.
‘Please meet me there as soon as you can, and I will share what I know. Très cordiales salutations, Alexandre’

Thomas-Alexandre goes on to describe a particular fountain deep in the city. He’d like to meet with you in secret, as he’s worried about someone intercepting the letter. Is your enemy really that powerful?

‘Chère Yvette, I’m truly glad that I was fortunate enough to meet you all those nights ago. However, I cannot stand that it came at the cost of such injustice being committed against you by that treacherous host. To that end, I’ve spent the last few days gathering intelligence and believe that I have found something that you will find quite interesting.’
Opening it up, you find a letter from Thomas-Alexandre, written with a precise penmanship that makes you think of expensive tutors, diligent practice, and military discipline.
The next morning, you find a letter on your nightstand. Camille must have brought it in while you were still asleep. It’s sealed in blue wax with the initials “A.D.”

(You have lost some favor with Louis Antoinne de Saint-Just)
(You have gained some favor with Elisabeth Vigee Le Brun)
You grace the voyeurs with a haughty sneer before leaving towards your own carriage.
Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to a mysterious stranger.
You consider the extravagant carriage for a moment, is this who you’d like to ride with?
Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to an honorable stranger.
You consider the bold carriage for a moment, is this who you’d like to ride with?
Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to a modest stranger.
You consider the humble carriage for a moment. Is this who you’d like to ride with?

The carriage to your right is richly decorated, yet somber. Swags of black crepe hang from the roof of the carriage, leaving only glimmers of the gold underneath. The decidedly feminine bent of the decorations indicates that the occupant is a woman, but all of the black suggests that she’s in mourning.

The carriage in front of you is obviously being used by a soldier of some sort. The driver is leaning intently towards the passenger compartment, waiting for orders. You recognize the insignia of the Queen’s Dragoons on the side of the carriage. It feels noble and proud, but also capable.

The carriage to the left of you is of foreign design, and features a gilded crest as its only ornamentation. This crest is emblazoned with a motto in latin, and appears to belong to a priest of some description. The curtains are drawn, but someone appears to have lit a lantern inside. Judging by the occupant’s silhouette, it looks like he’s reading.
However, there appear to be three other carriages waiting to leave, each of them quite different. Perhaps one of them can help?

Before you can even respond, he gets his carriage moving, leaving you alone with yet another indignity. 

Going back to Maximin is obviously unacceptable, it’s too far to walk home, and most of the other guests have already left.

You check to make sure that you’re in the right place, but to no avail. The carriage you hired is simply not there.
 
“He went home!” a passing coachman says helpfully, while adjusting the harness on a particularly grumpy horse. “Doorman came out about an hour ago, and told him you wanted the coach to leave without you. Seemed real important, so he went home.”

Scanning the faces of your new audience, you see the glaring, unamused faces of the various party guests. You’re certain that your hatred of Maximin, the Revolution, and everything else he stands for is going to be well known throughout the city soon enough.

However, when you arrive at the place where your carriage is parked, you quickly find out that… it isn’t. 

It’s gone.

Boiling over with anger, you turn and rain insults upon the house. In fact, you consider throwing your shoe through one of their windows, before you remember how much you like that shoe. It’s then that you notice that several of the carriages have stopped, just to watch your display.

Choosing to take the high ground, you straighten your posture and hold your head high, striding towards your carriage as if it was your intention to leave like this all along. While you make a great effort to haughtily avoid eye contact with all of those watching you, you can tell that some of them are quite surprised by your decorum in this dire situation.
The only thing left to do is go home.

When you finally get to the door, you feel a brutish shove, and you stumble out into the courtyard, barely keeping your balance in your heels. The area is equally crowded, with various persons entering their personal carriages. 

You can hear somebody snicker, but you have no idea who it was.

Before you can reply, a valet grabs you roughly by the arm and drags you from the study. People like your loathsome host don’t need to do their own dirty work, they have servants for that. It takes far longer than you’d like to get outside, as the entryway is crowded with guests preparing to leave.
 
You can feel their eyes weighing heavily on you.
"Perhaps not, I'll examine the other carriages."
"A wealthy widow, helping a lost soul in need? It works in the books. Let's go."
"Perhaps not, I'll examine the other carriages."
"He's a man of honor, sworn to protect France. I'm the next best thing to that. Let's go!"
"Perhaps not, I'll examine the other carriages."
“A priest should be willing to help a poor, innocent woman like myself. Let’s go.”
<Inspect the extravagant carriage to the right>
<Inspect the bold carriage in the middle>
<Inspect the humble carriage to the left>
"That's some big talk about titles, from a man who can't even do his own dirty work!"
*Sigh* "This has been a night. I'll just leave."

You politely slip away from him, and his increasingly desperate suggestions. You take this opportunity to explore the rest of the tavern. Flirting with strangers isn't half as fun if there's nobody there to see you do it.

"Madame, I believe this is where we part ways." Your newfound guide says, gently pulling away from you.

Sensing the shift in the conversation, he tries to win you over, but the drinks he's had finally seem to be catching up with him. 

"But madame, we can, escort... there." He points towards a table that's crowded with some of his friends. One of them waves awkwardly to you.
"Oh madame, you know where to find me when you're ready!" He says with a happy grin before going to request another bottle from the tavern keeper.
"I'm thinking about grabbing another bottle of wine, care to join me?"

With that in mind, you stroll around the tavern looking for Armand, arm in arm with a stranger. Eventually, you realize that Armand is nowhere to be found and that your playful deception has been a waste.

Or, at least, simply practice.
Once that happened, Armand would woo you back from the hapless object of your deception and life would go on. Nobody ever got hurt, and there was simply something fun about it.

"Well, that is what I offered to help you do." The man grimaces, and begrudgingly holds out his arm. You take it happily as he conducts you about the tavern, visiting all the places that you suspect Armand might be.

This isn't the first time you've flirted with strangers since you were engaged. Armand often got so wrapped up in his political endeavours that you'd feel ignored. A few coy glances in the wrong direction were usually enough to get Armand to remember that you, and a world outside his furious letter writing, existed.
"Now, where are you looking to go?"
He walks away to rejoin his friends, who appear to be even deeper into the wine than he is.
"Madame, I have escorted you up and down. We have sought your Armand to no avail. I have done my duty." He says simply, and shrugs. "Now if you excuse me, I must return to my compatriots."
With a wave that is barely as polite as decorum requires, he departs to seek the affection of a different young woman.
"Madame, I believe this is where we part ways." Your newfound guide says, gently pulling away from you.

His brow furrows and he turns up his nose. "Madame, I'm just trying to help. There's no need to be so rude."

You didn't think that refusing an invitation from a stranger was rude, but perhaps he was raised to think otherwise. Judging by the stares of the other patrons in the tavern, they seem to feel the same way as yourself.

(You have gained a little credibility)
The surprised man's face broadens into a happy grin as you reach out and take his arm. "Why it appears that I arrived just in time!"

Your turn around to find yourself face to face with an unfamiliar young man. He's well dressed and handsome enough, but it's the middle of day and he already smells like two bottles of wine. "Pardonne-moi madame, but I can never ignore the sight of a woman in need, and you appear to be lost."

"... something I offered to help you do." The man grimaces, and begrudgingly holds out his arm. You take it happily as he conducts you about the tavern, visiting all the places that you suspect Armand might be. A few of the patrons smirk at your clever ploy.

(You have gained a little credibility)
"May I... escort you?" His smile is broad and cocky.
You look around the unfamiliar tavern, trying to find Armand. Your eyes scan for his chestnut hair, your ears strain to hear the sound of his infectious laugh.
"Monsieur, I'm so glad to hear you can't refuse a woman in need! I need you to help me find my fiance."
"I'm fine for now, thank you."
"Perhaps, in a moment."
"I am trying to find my fiance, Baron Armand de Marbo. Can you help?"
"Oh, nowhere in particular, just around the tavern with you."
"What happened to be unable to refuse a woman in need?"
"Oui, I think it is."
"Non monsieur, you may not. I am fine by myself."
"Oh, you are so kind! Please do!"
Assets/Resources/Incidents/An Invitation: "If you head out today, you should be well prepared for the party tomorrow night."
(Le Petit Mogol is now available to visit in the Paris map)

"All I know is that this Baron de Termes is a very outspoken political type. Always going on about 'constitutions' and 'natural law'. Monsieur Armand attended a lot of his salons, but didn't always look happy when he came back from them."
"I'm sorry Madame, but I don't know much. It would have been improper for me to pry into Monsieur Armand's affairs." Camille replies with a surprising earnestness.
"You're expected to attend a party tomorrow, held by one Baron Maximin de Termes. I mean, Armand replied to the invitation, but you were to be his date."
"Judgemental! She was a little, very judgemental. I hope that helps, Madame."
"I know that she never visited the house. Monsieur Armand seemed to like her, but from what I could tell she was a little... how do I put this?"
"I hope that helps Madame."
"I'm sorry Madame, but a Viscountess... it just felt above my station, so I tried not to pay attention whenever she came up." Camille replies with a shrug.
"You're expected to attend a party the day after tomorrow, held by one Baron Maximin de Termes. I mean, Armand replied to the invitation, but you were to be his date."

"Fortunately, he knew the most delightful clothier on Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré. She runs a shop called 'Le Petit Mogol'. I’ll draw you some directions." Immediately she starts sketching some directions, mostly just simple renderings of local landmarks.

Camille continues. "Monsieur Armand was always going through clothes so quickly. He said that every outfit had a certain amount of novelty. Every time you wore them, the novelty would go down a bit. In fact, even a little thing like wearing the same thing twice in a row could run the novelty out faster. Can you imagine?"
At this proclamation, you can’t help but notice that Camille’s uniform has been repaired many, many times.
“Fortunately, the bad news was yesterday!”

"That reminds me!" Camille exclaims. "If you’re going to a party, you should probably make sure you’re dressed appropriately. Fashion moves so quickly here that people retire outfits before they even wear out!"

Camille looks nervously at the ground for a second, wringing her apron in her hands again.

“Well, after I told you about Monsieur Armand’s absence, you seemed upset. I felt like the last thing I should do was give you an obligation, right after bad news.”
Camille looks visibly relieved. “Parfait! If you need anything washed or prepared, just ask!”
“You’re expected to attend a party the day after tomorrow, held by one Viscountess Marcelle de Foix. I mean, Armand replied to the invitation, but you were to be his date.”

Early the next morning, Camille approaches you, occasionally wringing her apron with her hands. She’s obviously nervous.

“Madame, there’s something you should know…” Taking a deep breath, she continues.
"Camille, do you know anything about this Baron Maximin?"
"Camille, why didn't you tell me about this invitation sooner?"
"Well, at least I have a party to go to!"
"Camille, why didn't you tell me about this invitation sooner?"
"Well, at least I have a party to go to!"
"What do you know about the Viscountess de Foix?"
"What? Why didn't you tell me sooner?"
"Splendid! A party!"
"What? Why didn't you tell me sooner?"
"Splendid! A party!"
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Antoine's Inv: You check his directions against your map. If you head out now, it might be possible to meet up with Antoine today.
(Direct Action is now available to visit in the Paris map)
'Fear not. I'm certain that you will enjoy this as much as the royalists will hate it. Affectueusement, - Antoine'

'<i>Chere<i> Yvette,

I've grown dissatisfied with the ceaseless inaction of my peers and have decided to do something myself. I would like you to join me, should you find yourself inclined to the cause of liberty'

The letter goes on to describe a location where you could meet him.

You break the seal with a deft slice from your letter opener. You can immediately tell that the handwriting is Antoine's. He writes quickly enough that you can find small spatters of ink at the top of his compressed, precise letters.

This morning, it takes you a touch longer than usual to leave the warm cocoon of your blankets. When you do, you notice that Camille has left a letter on your nightstand. The wax seal shines red like fresh blood.
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Apprehended.a: You start the walk home, already relishing the idea of a hot meal, a long bath, and a fresh change of clothes.

Without so much as an apology, you’re lead out onto the street, and the door of the watch post is slammed loudly behind you. A few gawkers note your bedraggled state and you can easily assume that the fact that you just spent a few days in a jail cell is going to make it to all the right people.
(+1 Scandal)
You start the walk home, already relishing the idea of a hot meal, a long bath, and a fresh change of clothes

A few gawkers note your bedraggled state and you can easily assume that the fact that you just spent a few days in a jail cell is going to make it to all the right people.
(+1 Scandal)
With neither a chastisement nor an apology, you’re lead out onto the street, and the door of the watch post is shut loudly behind you. Just like that, you’re free.

Ludovico disappears into the crowds, leaving you and Hansel alone. A few gawkers note your bedraggled state and you can easily assume that the fact that you just spent a night in a jail cell is going to make it to all the right people.

You take some comfort in knowing that at least you’re not in prison anymore.
(+1 Scandal)

“I see!” Ludovico replies, clapping his hands together as if that just answered everything. “While I would absolutely love to stay, I unfortunately have a lot more prisons to visit before the day is up. May we meet again soon, under better circumstances.” Ludovico says, with a slow and polite nod of his head. You reply with the appropriate curtsey. Hansel gives a grunt of appreciation.
“Ja. The city has many doors. Some of them are more dangerous than others. Madame Decaux pays me to make sure they’re opened, or kept shut.”
“Her dooman?” Ludovico asks, his eyes resting on Hansel’s recently returned sword.
“My name is Hansel, Father.” Hansel replies gruffly. “I am Madame Decaux’s doorman.”
Ludovico turns to Hansel “It has also been delivered unto you… Singore...”
You start the walk home, already relishing the idea of a hot meal, a long bath, and a fresh change of clothes.

Ludovico quickly disappears into the crowds, and you are left alone. A few gawkers note your bedraggled state and you can easily assume that the fact that you just spent a night in a jail cell is going to make it to all the right people.

You take some comfort in knowing that at least you’re not in prison anymore.
(+1 Scandal)
“May we meet again soon, under better circumstances.” Ludovico says, with a slow and polite nod of his head. You reply with the appropriate curtsey.
“Your freedom, has been delivered unto you, Yvette.” Ludovico pronounces, with a dramatic sweep of his hands.
“I wouldn’t say ‘random chance’. After all, the Lord works in mysterious ways.” Ludovico replies with a shrug.
“But please, I would rather have this conversation somewhere less… dank and depressing.” Ludovico gestures towards the door. “After you, Yvette.”
“And yet with all of this knowledge, I’m still hoping to know you better.”
“Obviously, you couldn’t possibly be guilty of any crime, so I decided to intercede,” he says with a wink.

He turns to you with a wry smile. “Now imagine my surprise, when on my way to tend to the souls of the thugs and cutpurses of the 7th Arrondissement, I happen to see your name among the roll of prisoners.”

“I also find that knowing what the criminals are up to is a great way to understand what’s really happening in a city.” Ludovico admits with a shrug. “This allows my letters to Rome be a little more… complete.”
“I could go on, but I would rather have this conversation somewhere less… dank and depressing.” Ludovico gestures towards the door. “After you, Yvette.”

“I find that the best way to deal with the powerful is make myself a balance of ‘helpful samaritan’ and ‘irritating nuisance’. If they give me what I want, then I solve one of their problems, and they don’t have to deal with me anymore. I get what I want, and they still get to feel like they won.” He says idly, examining your cell.

“Your freedom, Yvette, has been delivered unto you.” Ludovico pronounces, with a dramatic sweep of his hands, before continuing. “While I would absolutely love to stay with you and help you celebrate it, I unfortunately have a lot more prisons to visit before the day is up.”

Outside, you breathe deeply, tasting fresh air for the first time in a while. It’s a simply pleasure, but one you already missed. The city continues in its daily routine, as if nothing had even happened.
“But I would rather have this conversation somewhere less… dank and depressing.” Ludovico gestures towards the door. “After you, Yvette.”
“Well, you see signora, I must admit that I’ve never had to deal with a case as… interesting as your own. I think we’d have to see each other quite a lot before I found some kind of solution.”
“I have to admit, I didn’t expect us to meet again under these circumstances.” Ludovico says with a mischievous grin.

With a weary nod, the watchman leaves the room and shuts the door behind himself. 

You don’t hear the door lock.
“Yes, I will be collecting her hireling as well. Leave us, my son,” Ludovico commands, his voice steely and stern.

“One of my many duties in the city is visiting prisoners for confessionals. After all, those who’ve fallen into wickedness are the ones who need our Lord’s guidance the most.” He gestures to the Bible in his hands. It’s well cared for but also well worn, without any gilding or ornamentation.

“If by ‘power’, you mean ‘the watchmen can’t make me leave, and giving up a minor criminal is better than having me stand in their post loudly abjuring their immortal souls all day’ then yes, I have that power.”
Ludovico smiles at your reply, and for a moment he looks you up and down in silence.
“I have to admit, I didn’t expect us to meet again under these circumstances.” Ludovico says with a mischievous grin.

With a weary nod, the watchman leaves the room and shuts the door behind himself. 

You don’t hear the door lock.
“Leave us, my son,” Ludovico commands, his voice steely and stern.
“Here she is, Father Sidotti,” the watchman sighs. He looks like he just wants this entire ordeal to be over. “Her associate is being held a few cells over, will you be needing that one too?”
“Here she is, Father Sidotti,” the watchman sighs. He looks like he just wants this entire ordeal to be over.
The shouting continues for a little while longer until you hear the jingling of keys, and the creaking of the door being unlocked.
“No, I shall not be calm! In the name of Saint Nicholas of Myra, you will turn this lost soul over to my care! You will do this for the sake of her soul, and dare I say, for you own!”
“What is the meaning of this? You’re keeping a lost and vulnerable Christian woman in need of guidance, amongst this loathsome squalor? Have you no shame?”
“... and trespassing. We didn’t find anything stolen, and you didn’t really do anything else. So after three days, you’re free to go!”

“What were you charged with?” the watchman asks, indignant at any attempt to question his authority. He scowls, and begins to stretch the limits of his imagination. “Well, you were trespassing and…” 

It’s an impressive effort, with unimpressive results.

“I mean, we can keep you here for longer, but we’d have to start charging rent,” the watchman replies with a shrug. “We looked into your background and it doesn’t look like you’re an enemy of the crown. You were just trespassing, and it felt like three days in a cell was enough.”
“Alright madame, you’re free to go.”
The morning of the third day, the door opens.

You dream fitfully that night, your sleeping mind trying to compensate for your lack of waking activity by bombarding you with every colorful and outlandish imagery imaginable. At least one of them is a fat rat in a waistcoat.

The next morning, you are so bored that you have decided to name the rat. His name is François-Louis, and he is a successful restauranteur in the rat community. He hoped to serve your shoes to his patrons as a lavish delicacy.

You can’t wait to get out of here.

That night, you wake up to find the fatest rat you’ve ever seen crawling on your leg and trying to eat your shoes. With a few choice words and some shakes of your leg, you manage to shoo it away. 

The obese thing squeaks indignantly at you before waddling away and squeezing into a hole in the wall.

The next day, you bang at the cell door to ask what you’ve been charged with. One of the watchmen says he’ll go find out, but you never hear from him again. The others don’t even bother to answer you.
Your malaise is suddenly interrupted by the distant sound of a commotion, followed by the enraged shouts of a familiar voice...

That morning turns to night. Meals are pushed through a slot in the door, and you do your best to stomach the lumpy, tasteless food. While you could refuse to eat out of spite, you get the feeling that the guards would barely notice.

An hour later, you’re sitting alone in a dark cell back at the Guet Royal’s watch post. You’re not sure what you’ve been charged with, but this is obviously less than ideal. 

Hansel’s been placed in a seperate cell, but you can hear him cursing to himself in German occasionally, so you know he’s fine.
You feel yourself being jostled in the sudden melee like a piece of flotsam in a turbulent river. You try to find an exit, a way to flee, but it’s a struggle just to stay standing.
The hours pass until morning. You feel nothing, other than the truly stultifying boredom of being locked in a stone box by yourself.

An hour later, you’re sitting alone in a dark cell back at the Guet Royal’s watch post. You’re not sure what you’ve been charged with, but this whole situation is obviously less than ideal. 

Somewhere else in the watch post, a pickpocket is screaming about his innocence. His alibi is getting more creative with every passing moment.
The watchman grabs you by the wrist. Hansel grabs him by the throat. People start screaming. More watchmen appear. Everything starts getting louder and more chaotic with every passing moment.

Accusations are shouted. A sergeant with breath that stinks of cheap wine demands to know who you’re working for, his fat fingers dangerously close to your face. Everything starts getting louder and more chaotic with every passing moment.
The watchman grabs you by the wrist, his calloused hand feels like a vice. You pull back and scream in shock. Alarmed by the sound, more of the watchmen’s compatriots appear.
The next few moments are a blur.
“So, it was just random chance?”
“So, it was just random chance?”
“You know me so well.”
“How did you know I was here?”
“How did you know I was here?”
“Can you actually free me? Do you have that power?”
“Oh, but Father, I just thought you were here to save a wicked woman’s soul.”

“I know that isn’t the whole answer, or what you want to hear. However, I need you to trust me Yvette, please.”

His voice is serious. Grave. Pained.
“I promise that I’ll explain all of this when it’s over.”
“Still, thank you. It makes me glad to know I still have you on my side.”
Armand looks away, staring out across the lake. “It’s something… something that I cannot tell you about. Not yet.”

“Ideas about modernity, monarchy, and what makes France different from the rest of the world.” Armand says, almost automatically, before looking away from you and blushing for a moment. His breath mists in the air, as he stares out across the still waters of the lake.

Isaac’s eyes widen and he seemingly notices you for the first time. “Oh… hello Madame. I was just giving your fiance some important files that he forgot at home. Please excuse my intrusion. Bonne nuit.”

Breathing deeply, Armand recomposes himself, and gestures in your direction.

“Isaac, have you met my fiance Yvette Decaux? We were just enjoying our last night together before I left to prepare for the general assembly.”
“Isaac!” Armand barks sharply and suddenly. Even the crickets and the birds seem to go silent.

“Armand, I know this is hard, but France itself is at stake here.” Isaac continues, oblivious to your presence. “We helped guarantee your election for our Bailliage, so you could do this for us. You said it yourself ‘We must-”
“Isaac…” Armand presses at a louder volume, glancing towards you.

“Armand, things are changing faster than we could have imagined,” the man called Isaac says, hurriedly pressing a small satchel into Armand’s hands. In the dim light you manage to notice the a few papers sticking out of the top of the bag. “We all knew tensions were going to keep rising after Bishop Bonteville killed himself, but this-”
Isaac looks back and forth between the two of you and gives a slow, formal bow. “Please excuse my intrusion. Bonne nuit.”

“The general assembly might be the last chance to keep this country on the proper course, which means we can take absolutely no chances.” Isaac glances significantly to the package now in Armand’s hands.

Your fiance is trying to look positive, but his expression falters slightly in the face of Isaac’s grave expression and warning.
“We share a lot of ideas in common.”
“That… was Isaac,” Armand says evenly. “I’ve been corresponding with him and some of his associates about politics for a few months now.

Armand exhales and smiles, but there’s still an air of tension about him.

“Not right now, no. It’s all… very vague at the moment. There’s so much going on that I don’t want to give you something new to worry about.”
With that, Isaac leaves. You and Armand stare at each other, silently, for over a minute.
Isaac looks back and forth between the two of you and gives a quick, formal bow. “You two are obviously in the middle of something important. Please excuse my intrusion. Bonne nuit.”

Isaac regards you warily as he continues. “Armand, I’ll keep this short. We all knew tensions were going to keep rising after the riots in Grenoble, but it’s happening faster than any of us would have ever imagined.”
Isaac winces as if he’d been cut. “I’m so sorry madame, that was very rude of me. It’s a pleasure to finally make your acquaintance.”
“And who might you be, madame?”

He pulls you closer and stares out at the lake. “I know I’m doing the right thing for France by going, but I’m going to miss moments like this,” he sighs.

Armand breathes deep, preparing himself for his next words.
“Isaac… what a surprise,” Armand starts, his voice flat and tense.
Isaac places a small leather case in Armand’s hands. “I just wanted to make sure that he didn’t forget these documents. It’s quite fortunate that I found him in time.”

Eyes widening for a moment, this man seems to notice you for the first time. 

“I... am Isaac, a good friend of Monsieur Armand,” he states, slowly and carefully. “I was afraid he’d already left for the general assembly.”
Your town is relatively small, and yet you still don’t recognize this man.

It’s then that a man stumbles out of the darkness towards you, glancing about himself, and trying to catch his breath. 

“Armand, I’ve been looking everywhere for you!” he whisper hoarsely.

You pull away from each other, and you stare into his eyes. His face is a mixture of excitement and surprise. He whispers to you “I hope every kiss we have is as good as that one.” 

Armand breathes deep, preparing himself for his next words.
You’re not sure how long your kiss lasts, time seems to have lost some of its importance.
“Yvette, I-” Armand starts, but stops. His talent for words seems to have failed him. Instead, he leans in towards you, his eyes closed.

You sit on your newfound bench with Armand, your bodies close together for warmth. Side by side, you stare out at the lake. Its water is so still that it almost seems like a mirror, the luminous reflection of the full moon is only lightly obscured the by occasional passing motes of fog dancing across the lake’s surface.

He uses his sleeve to sweep the snow off the wide piece of stone, then gestures out towards the lake your town is built on the edge of.

“Our new bench may not be the most prestigious real estate, but the view is quite nice, and the company’s the best in the world.”

You gently pull away and place a finger on his lips. He opens his eyes and blushes.

“Of course, we could keep enjoying the view, for a little while longer...”
Your lips meet his and a joyful shiver runs through your body. His hand comes up to stroke the side of your face as his other arm hugs you close.
Without a word, Armand leans in towards you, his eyes closed.

Your head leans on his shoulder. His body feels both warm and familiar.

The moon is full, the town distant, and it feels like you’re the only two people in the entire world.
You walk along the edge of a lake, the only sound being the chirping of the crickets, the sounds of your footfalls, and the steady rhythm of each other’s breath.

Armand smiles, “Very well, Madame!”. 

There’s not much in the way of benches outside the tavern, but he finds a stone mounting block a short distance from the tavern.
You step in close to him, wrapping your arm around his, before you both wander off into the moonlit night.
He turns and holds out his elbow for you to grab onto, “Care for a walk?”
“While I like Le Cygne as much as the next man, I’d prefer to end our night with something that’s just about us.” Armand says in a soft, low voice.

Outside the night air is brisk, even the colors of the moonlit sky are cold. It’s a stark contrast from the fireside warmth of the tavern. Yet, despite the open air, it feels more intimate and personal than the small tavern you’ve left behind.
He then fills his own, then raises his glass for a toast. “To the loss of our hero, destroyed by that which he loved the most.”
He waves to barmaid, who brings you a bottle of wine and some glasses, along with a loaf of freshly baked bread that’s still steaming when it touches the table. Armand fills your glass first.

Armand sighs, “Oh, a tragic ending for our hero. If only he had never been late to see his captivating fiance, this never would have happened.”
“Ah, the kindling embers of true love would be reignited into a roaring flame. I would cast off my disguise, and you would completely forgive me for being late.”
“What say you, wicked woman of the woods? Would you be swayed by this huntsman’s charms?”
“Obviously, I would be unable to resist your charms. Perhaps… you would feel same?”

Armand leans in, his eyebrow raised conspiratorially, “Ah, but your evil ways would not go unnoticed for long. I would disguise myself as a huntsman, lost in the forest and pretend to be blissfully unaware of your wicked predations. While I would be unable to resist your charms, I feel that… you might feel the same way about me.”

Armand is more animate now, his words coming out faster and faster “In that case, I shall have no choice but to disguise myself as a huntsman, lost in the forest, and happening upon your grand salon by chance. You might be intrigued by this curious outsider in your midst. This would lead us to talking amongst the birds, the deer, and your other refined guests about the natural order, and the beauties of the wilds.”
“How will you pass your time alone in the woods?”

Suddenly he begins to perk up, and leans in close to whisper. “You’ll finally leave this place behind, living as a lonely hermit, far from the prying eyes of civilization. At night, children will whisper of the beautiful, wicked woman living in the forest, who reviles all of society.”

He pauses, and takes a deep breath. “Enough of that! If I want to feel sorry for myself, I can do it on the carriage to Paris. Tonight is for making sweet memories.”

He waves to barmaid, who brings you a bottle of wine and some glasses, along with a loaf of freshly baked bread that’s still steaming when it touches the table.
“I knew it...” Armand sighs, defeated.

Armand gives an audible sigh of relief, while he usually cares about keeping his appointments, he rarely let’s something like this get to him. “I’m sorry, it’s just… the general assembly is so important, but so are you. I’m packing and writing letters night and day in order to get ready, but all the time I spend on that is time I’m not spending with you.”

With the wine finished, Armand pauses to place the bottle on its side, a curious habit he picked up from his father. He then takes a deep breath, and waits a moment before saying “The snow appears to have stopped. Would you… would you like to join me outside? I have something I want to show you.”

You spend an hour finishing the bottle together, pausing occasionally to nibble at the bread. All the while, you trade jokes, news from around the village, and simply try to forget that this is the last you’ll see of each other for months.
The red wine is deep and full bodied, it smells of leather, blackberries and cloves. It’s some of the best you’ve had, and you can tell that Armand is enjoying it as well.
He then fills his own, then raises his glass for a toast. “To France, to the general assembly, but most importantly, to us!”
Armand fills your glass first. “My father’s been talking my ear off about this particular vintage. I hope it’s up to your standards.”

“Excellent! This is our last night together for a while, so I want to make sure that it’s a memory we’ll treasure.”

He waves to barmaid, who brings you a bottle of wine and some glasses, along with a loaf of freshly baked bread that’s still steaming when it touches the table.

"Yvette? Is that you?" He whispers to you, frantically. "What are you doing here?"
After a while, you manage to find Monsieur Clet. He looks thin and bedraggled. Also his clothes have obviously not been changed in days. You use a nearby ring of keys to let yourself into his cell.
Wandering the darkened halls of the prison, you suddenly come face-to-face with Ludovico.
Spotting no other guards in the area, you start searching the cells for a man matching the description of Monsieur Clet that Antoine gave you.
You breathe deeply as you step inside, savoring the cool air of the stone building. Unfortunately, it smells like stagnant water, musty old hay, and desperation.
The thick, concealing garments could come in handy...
As for how you're actually supposed to do that... well, you're still working that out. You certainly don't know how to pick a lock.
Monsieur Clet's situation is terrible, but you simply don't have the ability to do anything about it. He's on his own now.
With a bitter sigh, you turn away from the Château de Vincennes and start to head home.
You compose yourself, and weigh your options.
"Fine... fine... I'll let you in for a few minutes to see your brother." He sighs, looking around to make sure that none of his superiors are watching.
(You have lost some credibility... but it's probably worth it)
You run from him until you're out of sight, and nearly out of breath.

(You have lost quite a bit of of credibility)
(You have gained quite a bit of peril)
"Now!" He screams, and you start leaving faster.
You turn to leave, and carefully begin to walk away.
He examines your fake tears, then narrows his eyes. "Madame, you need to leave. Right now."
Just as you appear to be on the verge of a hysterical breakdown, the guard sighs and relents. It's not your proudest moment, but you can't argue with results.
You thank the guard for his time, and follow his directions to the nunnery next door.
"Same amount of prayers for deliverance, though!" He laughs. "Though, I think the Lord is only heeding the prayers coming from next door."
"Oui madame, that is next door." He replies, then points with his thumb at the heavy prison door behind him. "This place here holds a less godly type of soul."

"What? I've not heard about any of this!" He says, putting down his pipe. "Who agreed to this? I need a signed letter from the warden, first!"

You put on your best innocent face, and start to force tears into your eyes.
"Can I help you, madame?" He asks, not even taking the pipe out of his mouth.
A woman who spent her life devoted to the Lord, and another one put there by her fed-up family. Surely, God would know the difference between the two, right?

You giggle at the memory of all the times your angry parents threatened to send you to a nunnery for some mischeif you'd wrought in town. Looking around, you can't help but wonder how many women here are actually here because they want to be here, and how many were enrolled by force.

You go around the right side and examine the nunnery. It's peaceful and clean, but sparse in terms of any ornamentation. You spot a small group of nuns walking and talking together, but they keep their distance from you.
You head to the left side, where you find the entrance to the prison. The door is guarded by a single guard, who seems more occupied with smoking his pipe than with vigilance.
You spot Château de Vincennes just up ahead, and consider your next move.
Dabbing a few droplets of sweat from your brow, you curse the heat, and the almost suspiciously sunny weather. You consider putting up your hood, but decide it would make you stand out too much.
It's a long walk to Château de Vincennes, and you pass the time by reviewing your task again. You're here to free Monsieur Clet, a printmaker sympathetic to the revolution.

"I see you've been deep in your cups, and some strong stuff by the smell of it..."

Your heart stops in your chest.

"I'll remember the 1783 Salon for the rest of my life. I made two paitings. 'Peace Bringing Back Abundance' was there to show I could do more than portraits, but my real focus was 'Marie en Chemise'. I poured my heart into that painting. It was relaxed, calm and kind. It was the Marie I knew. It was the Marie I wanted to show the world."

"By then Marie had been rejected enough times to be sick of politics and intriques. So, instead she spent her efforts making a simple world of leisure in that chateau. Like a little island isolated from the rest of France."
"Instead I met Marie and her friends at Le Petit Trianon, and joined them in their leisure. I saw them as themselves, not as the masks they wore at court."

"I had a good reputation, and I'd painted nobility before, even a few relatives of the Queen, but those were formal paintings. I would show up, chat with them a little, and try to capture the essence of someone I didn't even know. Marie was something else entirely."
"I feel like I betrayed her."

"A few years later, I painted another painting of her, something with her children. I made what the academy wanted to see. More austere, more appropriate, something befitting the mother of the king's children. Since then, Marie and I have lost touch."
"Marie never questioned my motives. She didn't even think about it. She just did it. Suddenly, I was a member." Elisabeth says with a confused shrug.

"We became friends of a sort."

Elisabeth turns her eyes away from you and to the ground.
Elisabeth laughs "She could never stay on key, but that wasn't important."

"Courtiers spent their lives scheming and lobbying to see Marie-Antoinette, Queen of France and mother of the nation. I got to know the real Marie, gentle and considerate. We would sing duets together after our painting sittings."
A duo of tears roll down her cheeks. "But it wasn't. My infamy only brought me more clients, and the common people loved it. Marie was more damaged by the scandal than I was."

"I was surrounded by all these men, these master artists, whose work I admired. I had to listen to them tear it to pieces. That my portrait was scandalous. That it was insulting. That it was unbecoming of the Queen."
"And they hated it."

"I'd spend the day relaxing with with Marie, Polignac, Rose, and the Queen's other favorites in Le Petit Trianon, only a stone's throw from Versailes. No court, no rituals, no massive ball gowns." She sighs "Just us women. Free to enjoy ourselves on our terms."

Before you can even utter a word, Hansel has his saber out and pointed at your assailant. His voice is a low ursine rumble "Unhand the woman, or die. Your choice."
When your eyes adjust to the light, you realize that your assailant is none other than Antoine. He's pressed so close to you against the wall, that you can feel his rapid heartbeat through his coat.
Suddenly, you feel a hand reach across your body, grab you by the shoulder and pull you into an alley.

You've reached the end of your directions, so you must be in the right place. However, there's nothing that seems particularly special about this address. You glance around and find the streets to be empty. There's no sign of Antoine at all.

The nighttime sky is overcast and the streets smell of freshly finished rain. You use one hand to adjust your hood while you look down at the directions Antoine provided in his letter. You glance around at the buildings and note that you've found yourself in one of the nicer neighborhoods in Paris. In fact, you're not from La Place Royale.
"Camille, that boy is going to be the death of me."
"It was incredibly exciting."

"Without finishing what we started? Never!"
"Agreed."

<Carefully place your posters>

"Do you invite every girl that you fancy out to commit crimes, against the Crown?"

Assets/Resources/Incidents/Gentlemanly D: Inside, you carefully step over Camille, who fell asleep in the hallway. You creep upstairs to undress and chronicle the evening's events in your journal. Unfortunately, you can't help but replay the evening's events in your head, and wonder what could possibly come next after that.

Inside, you gently step over Camille, who happens to be sleeping in the hallway. Heading upstairs to undress and to chronicle the evening's events in your journal, you wonder when you'll next learn more of this mysterious soldier.
"Bonne nuit, Yvette." Alexandre says with bow. "Shall I see you again soon?"
Before you know it, you arrive at your humble home. Camille doesn't come out to greet you, but given the late hour, that's unsurpring.
You both do a decent job it, and manage to almost forget that boorish man's attempts to spoil your evening.
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
"Thank you for asking, Yvette. As you can imagine, I rarely have occasion to discuss these sorts of things."
"I wanted to make something of myself, and it only brought him shame."
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
The two of you walk and talk, and try to settle yourselves after what transpired.
"Who the devil are you, to ask this of me?"
His next words are a whisper, one only you can hear.
"My father forbade me from enlisting under the family name. He felt I would be dragging it through the mud..."
"Still, you make fine company, even when we're beset by the most boorish louts in Paris!"
"I'm... I'm fine as well."
"Are you alright?"
He marches off into the night, presumably to be terrible to someone else.
The grimy man stares at both of you expectantly, until he finally tires of your silence, and turns to leave.
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
Alexandre looks to you, and gives a confident nod.
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
Alexandre looks to you, and gives a confident, thankful nod.
"Do you wish to disrespect your Queen, God preserve her, or do you wish to be as polite as decorum requires?"
"... Dumas isn't my real surname. It was my mother's."
He relaxes, letting tension release from his shoulders. "That's to be expected, I imagine. I appreciate your candor."
He looks uncertain. "That's good."
He turns to you with a wide grin, as if nothing had happened at all. "Sorry about that. I'm normally much better about this sort of thing."
Alexandre tensely watches the man until he's completely out of sight. The dragoon is shaking a little.
At this, the boorish man feels less sure of himself. He grumbles a half-hearted apology to the both of you and scurries away, taking great care to avoid eye contact with either of you.
"Madame is correct. I am one of the Queen's Royal Dragoons, and those who insult me insult Her Majesty herself."
At this, Alexandre straightens up again, this time placing his hand on the pommel of his sabre. "Monsieur, are you sure that's what you want to say to her?"
"... just the son of a slave..."
"I owe nothing to you, madame." He sneers. "If you dislike my behavior so much, then don't walk near my house!"
At this, Alexandre straightens up again, this time placing his hand on the pommel of his sabre.
"I am... nobody..."
"I am... I am..."
"I am-" Alexandre begins, but halts suddenly. He steps backwards, less sure of himself.
While taken aback at first, the grimy man who treated you so rudely, sneers and replies "I shall do no such thing!"
"Have you taken leave of your senses, you loathsome imbecile? Do you think it is acceptable for a man to act this way? You will apologize to her, immediately!"

The dragoon marches over to this man and looms over him, but not with the force of a soldier preparing for yet another fight. There's something else about Alexandre's demeanor. He is incensed, haughty, and imperious.
His face controted with anger, Alexandre yells at the man walking away from you."You! Monsieur! Halt, right now!"
Without a word, this man shoves you out of the way and silently starts marching down the street.
The door of a house suddenly bursts open in front of you. A grimy man steps out.

You continue to walk together, sticking near the buildings to avoid getting struck by any reckless carriages that might come barrelling down the street. Coachmen these days are paid for speed, not safety.
(You've gained a little favor with Alexandre)
"Though I hope you manage to find a more worthwhile reason to stay."
(You've gained some favor with Alexandre)
"I feel much the same way." He replies, squeezing your hand gently.
"I suppose that's true." He admits.
He nods along. "A good reason. History is being made every day, but here feels like the center of it all. You can feel the tension in the air. You can feel the passion burning in people's hearts."
"You've had every reason to leave Paris, yet you're still here. Why?"
"As for myself, I'm not sure if I really miss my family, such as it was..."
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
"There's no need to apologize, at all. Blood is all well and good, but it doesn't have to be the most important thing. Never be ashamed for wanting to make something of your own."
He smiles at your reply. "I can understand that. If we are a seed then family is the soil in which we grow. However, if we stay too close, we might find ourselves wilting in their shade."
"My word, that must be very hard for you." He says with a shake of his head.
"You've been in Paris for quite some time. Do you miss your family at all?"
The conversation dies down somewhat when he takes hold of you, but that doesn't matter. The warmth of his body says enough.
Silently, he takes your hand.
Your rendezvous complete, you decide to head home. Alexandre insists on walking you there, saying that he'd never forgive himself if he let some misfortune befall you.
"I need some time to think. Tonight was... a bit much."
"Oh, but of course!"
"I should be asking you that. What happened back there?"
"I'm a little shaken as well."
"Don't worry, I'm fine."
<Say nothing>
"Monsieur, I'm the one you owe an apology to! Or is this how you treat all women?"
"Who is he? He's one of the Queen's Royal Dragoons, you ingrate!"
"I love the people here. There's a passion that I'm drawn to."
"Paris is the lesser of two evils. Snubs and ridicule are better than insignificance."
"What happens in Paris is the future of France, and I want to see it happen."
"I'm sorry but it doesn't really bother me. I'm my own person."
"Yes and no. I love them, but I can't be who I really am when I'm around them."
"I miss them quite a lot, actually."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Her Muse.asse:
In your room, you barely manage to get undressed before you collapse in your bed.

This has been quite a day.
Fitfully, you manage to get to sleep.
The painting sessions can't come soon enough.
Suddenly, she blurts it out. "Can you pose nude for me?"
She glances at you and opens her mouth to speak, but stops and looks away.
You stare at yourself in the mirror before you go to bed, and hesitantly practice a few poses. The thought of someone staring at you naked, for hours at a time, does little to calm your nerves.
Before you go to bed, you practice a few elegant poses in the mirror, imagining what it will be like to have your beauty immortalized by such an incredible artist.
When you get home, she gives you a wave goodbye and heads towards the main road.

Your walk the rest of the way home is quiet, with a few attempts at conversation that don't completely spring to life.

Elisabeth seems distracted.
You get home, and pace around your room, feeling a combination of nervousness, excitement and exhaustion.

"I think we'll both find this it very... inspiring." She flashes you a mischevious smile.

The two of you walk and talk together for a while longer, but your mind is swimming with the possibilities of what you just agreed to.

"It'll take a few sittings, but you can come by my studio whenever you like."

(You can now visit Elisabeth's studio for portrait sessions in the Paris Map)
"... it might also be about you being naked."

She flushes with embarassment. 

"No! That's not what I meant! I mean the painting isn't just about you being naked. It's about focusing on the ideal, to make a point."
"Naked portraits focus on realism, while nudity is about capturing the ideal."
"Well, not entirely. 'Nude' and 'naked' don't mean the same thing in art."
"Oh. That's too bad."

"Fantastique!"

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
"Yvette, would you like to pose nude for me?"
"I want to paint a new portrait, but not for a client. I want to make something more personal."
"Yvette, I... want to paint a new portrait, but not for a client. I want to make something more personal."
The feeling in the air grows tenser. She stops and starts a few more times before she finally says it.

She laughs, and while it isn't loud, it feels like a great pressure has been released.

"Nothing's wrong! I'm sorry, this isn't normally a problem for me."
She does it again.

After your rendezvous, Elisabeth offers to walk you home. The streets are empty, so you walk down the center of the road, arm in arm. While you can distantly hear the sound of the city's clamor from other streets, you feel like the only people in the world.
"Wait, nude? You want to do a naked portrait of me?"
"Wait, nude? You want to do a naked portrait of me?"
"Wait, nude? You want to do a naked portrait of me?"
"Wait, nude? You want to do a naked portrait of me?"

"Hmm... I don't think I can, sorry."
"In that case, I'd love to."
"What? Is the real thing not good enough?"
"Oh, really? So, is my real body not good enough?"
"I'm not chill with that"
"Sounds good to me."
"Nude? You want to do a naked portrait of me?"
"Nude? You want to do a naked portrait of me?"
"I don't think I can do that."
"I'd love to."
