Assets/Resources/Incidents/Home, Sweet H: Glancing around, Camille seems to notice your mountain of luggage for the first time. "Mon dieu Madame! Did you carry this all yourself? You must be exhausted!"

"I'm sure he's fine Madame," Camille replies with a tone of voice that doesn't fill you with confidence. "I'm sorry to tell you this, but I haven't seen Monsieur Armand in days. I was hoping he was with you."

She’s not wrong. You’re not certain how you’re still upright and awake right now. 
“I’ve already made up your bed Madame, please go inside and let me take care of this.” Camille insists.

While you’re still processing this latest disappointment, Camille seems to notice your mountain of luggage for the first time. “Mon Dieu, Madame! Did you carry this all yourself? You must be exhausted!”
You flop down on a nearby couch, open your diary, and start to write. You’re tired, disappointed, and perhaps abandoned, but writing things down always helps you make sense of a situation.

You take your diary and leave the heavy lifting to Camille. The inside of the house isn’t much better than the outside. Camille keeps the place tidy, but she can only do such much. Still, you don’t care about that right now, you’re just happy to have a roof over your head.

She’s not wrong. You’re not certain how you’re still upright and awake right now. 
“I’ve already made up your bed Madame, please go inside and let me take care of this.”
At this, Camille takes a deep, nervous breath. “I’m afraid to tell you that you’ll have to wait, Madame. It’s been days since I’ve seen Monsieur Armand. I was hoping that he was with you.”

“I’m sure he’s fine Madame,” Camille replies with a tone of voice that doesn’t fill you with confidence. Glancing around, Camille seems to notice your mountain of luggage for the first time. “Mon Dieu, Madame! Did you carry this all yourself? You must be exhausted!”
Eyeing her worn shoes, you have a feeling the rats didn’t go quietly.
“Impossible, Madame! I’ve taken care of all the rats myself.” Camille replies, emphasizing her point with a playful stomp of her foot.
“I… I was hoping that he was with you.” Camille replies hesitantly. “I haven’t seen him in days.”
“Ah, bonsoir! I assume you must be Madame Yvette! My name is Camille, Monsieur Armand told me to expect you.”

Calling the house ‘rustic’ would imply that you were out in the country, not in the center of a city. The neighborhood is nice enough, but you’re worried that if you breathe too hard on the building, it’ll fall over. A well kept woman in the attire of a maid opens the door and approaches you.
Still, you didn’t expect this...

You’re getting close to the address. Armand never described his living conditions much, but he’s the son of a Baron and his family was always well to-do, especially compared to yours. You’ve spent a lot of time in that carriage wondering about the home you’d spend your new life in.
You’re overseeing a grand salon, surrounded by poets, musicians, scientists, philosophers, and artists. You are elegant, sophisticated, and respected.
For a brief moment, you’re not a country girl dragging luggage through the streets. You’re the person you feel that you are, when you close your eyes, alone.

It’s the middle of the night, but the street is still teeming with life. The light from the windows and the street lamps sparkle like the stars. You’re tired and your feet hurt, but still, you can’t help but smile.

This is it. This is Paris. No matter what happens, you’re still here.

After waiting around for a few hours, you leave the Orphan’s Feast, dragging your small mountain of luggage behind you. After all, the coach was only hired to take you to the tavern. Armand may not have been waiting for you like he said he would, but you memorized his address from all of the times you wrote it on your letters to him.
“Uh… thank you Camille. Do you think Armand’s alright?”
“He has a lot of explaining to do.”
"Uh... thank you Camille. Do you think Armand's alright?"
“Fine. When I’m done, Armand is simply going to wish the rats had eaten him.”
"Is this where he lives? Oh God, the rats in there ate him, didn't they?"
"Merci Camille, please take me to Armand."
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Honorade's Cl: Honorade helps you down from the carriage, and with a crack of René’s whip, her carriage departs and winds its way into the city. You stop to think about this new information. Marcelle is a wealthy aristocrat, but her fortune appears to be younger than she claims. It seems like this knowledge could be useful, but you’ll have to dig deeper first.

Honorade signals to René and the carriage begins to roll to a stop. Pulling back the curtains for a moment, you realize that you’re already outside your home. “While we must unfortunately part ways,” Honorade says as René open the door. “I wish you the best of luck in your quest for vengeance.”

“Given what I saw from you that night, I have a feeling that you and I share a flare for the dramatic. I expect that whatever you choose to do will be suitably poetic, considering what she’s done to you.”
“I like you, and I despise Marcelle.” Honorade says, a simple statement of facts. “The idea of you toppling that tasteless wretch is extremely satisfying.”
“Of course, you could always just give up, but I don’t think that sort of thing suits you.”

“Now you pursue this lead, hatch a plan, and get your revenge. What that requires is really up to you. I’m more than happy to provide you with information, but I think you’ll be better served if you handle the rest yourself.”
“Oh my, yes.” She answers, making no attempt to hide how much she is relishing the current situation.
“Now?”
“That gaudy wretch is hiding something about her money. Knowing what she’s like in public, anything she wants to hide must be dark indeed.”

“Thirty years is a long time for a single person, but that’s not how the aristocratic families see the world. The Gazel family’s fortune is forty years old and we’re still derided as ‘new money’” Honoroade pauses to sip her water and sneer at some unseen adversary. 

“As if recent success was something to be ashamed of. To put it simply, why would her family pretend their fortune is older than it really is?”

“During those meetings, I asked about Marcelle’s family investments, and pretended to be very impressed with whatever they told me. However, in that whole time, I couldn’t find evidence that any of her family’s investments were older than thirty years or so.”

“So, I did what anyone else would do. I held meetings with as many of her business partners as I could, claiming to be interested in investing my husband’s fortune. They, of course, fell all over themselves in order to meet with me and try to part me from my late husband’s money.”

“It’s possible that you’re more forgiving than myself, but the thought of what happened to you that night still makes me livid. At first, I admittedly knew very little about Marcelle, but the more I started learning about her, the less I liked. Now that I’ve gotten to know her better, I’m not surprised at all that she would be so… contemptible.”

Honorade sips at her glass of water and spends a few moments simply looking you over. You’re not really sure what she’s looking for. After a while, she seems satisfied, and continues.

“Since you’re here, I’ll assume that you read my letter.”
You take her hand and get into the carriage. As with before, it takes a few moments for your eyes to adjust to the oppressive gloom within.

“Besides, this dress is silk and I’m not going to risk falling into a fountain with it on,” she continues and offers her hand to you. Judging from her tone, you get the feeling that disagreeing with her logic won’t get you anywhere.
Honorade follows you inside and takes up her normal seat across from you. With a silent signal to René, the carriage takes off.
As with before, it takes a few moments for your eyes to adjust to the oppressive darkness within.

Honorade laughs with an unexpected snort. “I’m sure that it’s not. However, anyone who wishes to spy upon us already knows who we are. The very least we can do is discuss this in a place where they can’t listen in.”
“Je t’en prie,” she replies, before offering her hand and helping you into the carriage.
“Please step inside, I would rather not share this information while in public.”
Honorade steps down from the carriage. “Bonjour Yvette, I hope you haven’t been waiting long.”

After only a few minutes of waiting by the fountain, Honorade’s carriage pulls up and René, Honorade’s trust coachman steps down off of his box to open the door for her. It’s the middle of the day, but the inside of the luxuriously decorated carriage is still shrouded in gloom.

You get comfortable, smooth out your skirts and pause for a moment to reflect on the decisions that led you to a point in your life where you’re having secret rendezvous with a glamorous widow to learn the secrets of your most hated enemies. If anything, they must have been some good decisions.

Looking around, you can’t spot Honorade anywhere, so you decide to take a seat at the edge of the fountain. It makes sense to be visible enough that she’ll be able to find you without any flashy waving or signalling.

Surprisingly enough, you manage to find the fountain without getting turned around. It seems like the perfect place for a meeting like this. There’s just enough people wandering around that you won’t draw attention, but also few enough that you’ll be able to find somewhere secluded to talk.
Given that you’re still new to skullduggery, you decided to dress in darker clothes, and stuck to comfortable walking shoes.
You leave the house earlier than usual that morning, uncertain of how long it’ll take you to walk to the fountain that Honorade mentioned in her letter to you.
“You’re enjoying this, aren’t you?”
"I think you’re right, what now?”
“Are you sure this carriage is… discreet?”
“Merci, Honorade.”
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Honorade's In: Fanning yourself with the letter to drive away some of the summer heat, you can't help but notice the smell of her perfume on the letter again. You idly realize that you could go there today if you wished.
(La Matresse de Commande is now available to visit in the Paris map)
'Here, there will be no chance of us being interrupted. I await your arrival.'
'Ch볥 Yvette, As of late, I've been feeling even even better than I did at the beginning of our last fateful encounter. My gardens are doing especially well, and I'd love for you to see them.'
You open it, and begin the read the letter. The flowing cursive of her handwriting is both beautiful and familiar.
There's a letter on the bedside table. Judging from the rich purple of the wax seal, as well as the scent of the perfume, it was definitely sent by Madame Gazel.
Just as you wonder what Camille has prepared for your breakfast, you notice the faint smell of perfume. It's both floral and bitter.
You wake up and stretch languidly. You slept well last night and already feel prepared to conquer yet another day.

Using your map, it doesn’t take long to figure out where this particular fountain is. In fact, you could visit it today if you like.
‘Please meet me there as soon as you can, and I will share what I’ve learned. Bien affectueusement, Honorade’
Honorade goes on to describe a particular fountain deep in the city. She’d like to meet with you in secret, as she’s worried about someone intercepting the letter. Is your enemy really that powerful?

‘Chère Yvette, It was truly a pleasure to have your company in the ride home from that otherwise dreary party. Still, I seethe at the thought that our host was allowed to ridicule you. The next morning, you find a letter on your nightstand. Camille must have brought it in while you were still asleep. It’s sealed with a rich purple wax seal, bearing the initials “H.G.”
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Internal Divi: He takes your hand in his own. "Though some are certainly smarter than others."
"I have plenty of allies here, even if they aren't always vocal."
"To prioritize one's own comfort like this... it's so selfish. Are we no better than beasts?"
With that, he turns and leaves, disappearing almost instantly into the crowd.
"You should write me soon. I'd love to meet you alone, where we can be away from all these half-hearted types." He whispers, gesturing dismissively at some of the other guests.
He pulls a clean, white handkerchief from his pocket and hands it to you. His name and address have been embroidered into it in red thread.

You do your best to maintain a low profile while you search for you next engagement at the party. Associating with someone like that may be necessary, but it rarely attracts the right sort of attention.
Swept up in a heady rush of emotion, you float about the party, searching for your next engagement.
Alone, you look down at the handkerchief in your hand.
(You can now go on rendezvous with Antoine)
However, you do notice that an address has been embroidered into it, in red thread. It might be very useful if you wanted to write him, or perhaps meet up with Antoine in the future.
He sighs. "It's true. I originally studied oratory and law, but my real passion in school was poetry and theater. There's just something special about fiction, myths, and legends."
(You have gained some favor with Antoine)
"With fiction, we can show people the truth in ways that even the best rhetoric can never accomplish. We can convince them to see the truth themselves."

"He is? Send him up, right away."
Camille laughs, but you're not sure if she gets the joke.
Love is joy, love is comfort, love is passion, but sometimes love is also catharsis.
"Once the rose colored lenses are lifted from your eyes, they can never be put back on, but that's alright. I can still be inspired by my memories."
"... because my father had made powerful enemies when he left Saint Domingue..."
"No... I have not..."
Trying to ignore the mental images of the lost souls that you so frequently discussed tonight, you trudge upstairs to record the details in your journal, before getting ready for bed.
With memories of the happy evening still in your mind, you head upstairs to record the details in your journal, before getting ready for bed.
"And you enjoyed yourself as well, madame?"
With that, Alexandre excuses himself and heads off into the night.
"I think Madame Decaux here is going to be a little more cautious when agreeing to mysterious invitations from now on, but otherwise I think things went well!" Alexandre jests.
"Bonsoir madame! Bonsoir monsieur! Did you enjoy your evening?"
The sun sets and with nightfall, he walks you home. You find Camille waiting for you outside.
(You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
His body is as still and powerful as a tree, but as you rest your head against his chest, you can hear his heart beating at a furious tempo.

Love is, of course, bigger than its grand romatnic gestures. The two of you spend the next hour watching the sunset, laughing and joking with each other. He regales with stories of daring that grow improbably with every telling.

Your lips meet. You fling your arms around his neck and he only holds you closer. Between throes of passion, your eyes open for but a moment, and you glimpse a single tear rolling down his cheek.
You wraps your arms around him and he hugs you close. Tightly and fiercely.
As you crane your neck to bring your lips closer to his, you feel one of his arms sweep behind your knees and he lifts towards himself, almost like a dancer's dip.
"...and love."
He loops his arm around your waist.
"Another day in the place that's been kinder to me than anywhere else in the world. It's given me freedom, education, excitement..."
You look to the horizon and realize that the sun is setting. You glimpse beautiful oranges and purples between the buildings of the Paris skyline.

He laughs loudly. "Yvette, if that's nothing to you, I can't wait to see what you think a real favor for your friends is."
"I'm sorry, but you should be able to understand why I wasn't comfortable putting some of this in a letter. This has not been easy."
He gives you a theatrical bow "I am in your debt."
"Thank you again. I don't think I could have done that by myself."
You walk outside with him, and notice that the funeral party from before has also finished up. While they still look somber, you can tell that they're also ready to move forward with their lives.
"Yvette, I think we should be on our way."
He kneels down, and with a handkerchief, cleans the smudges of dirt from the headstone. "Farewell father. I shall not return."
He looks at you and grins. "And I am so fortunate, to have people with me, who could help me when I was lost."
"Today, I am Thomas-Alexandre Dumas. I am a man who will help the downtrodden. One who will use his might, in service of right."
He sighs contentedly, as if letting down a great weight. "But none of that matters..."
He leans back his head and shouts "I am Thomas-Alexandre Davy de la Pailleterie, true heir to the title of the Marquis de la Pailleterie!"

"I like that idea." He smiles thinly, eyes still fixed on the headstone.
"No." He replies flatly. "I cannot live selfishly. I cannot live, as he lived."
"You're absolutely right. I must fight for others. I must do the things he would have never thought to do."
"I've been trying to live up to a great legacy... that isn't great at all."
"I thought that I should honor his memory, but now I'm starting to think that's wrong too."
"He served in the army as well. I joined up to make him proud, but when he died I realized that there was nobody left to be proud of me."

You arrive at a gravestone. It's carved from fine marble, but already marred with dirth and soot. It says 'Marquis Alexandre Antoine Davy de la Pailleterie'. A series of battles are listed under the name.
"I wouldn't be here, with all of my advantages, if he hadn't condemned them to that suffering."
(You have lost a little favor with Alexandre)
"... and because this all hapened nearly a decade ago!"
Seeing your confused expression, the anger leaves him, replaced only by melancholy. "The average lifespan of a working slave in Saint Domingue... is around ten years."
"What am I saying?" He growls, to himself more than anyone else. "It's not a feeling, it's an objective fact."
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
"... because they're thousands of miles away, where simple messages take months arrive."
"Yes, I do feel that," he sighs. "I'm glad you understand."
"That's true, I suppose. I never asked him for any of this." He admits.
"It's nice being your father's favorite, but sometimes..."
His next words are difficult, a creaking wheeze. "He sold my three siblings, and my mother. There was no policy set in place to buy them back. He never intended to see them again."
"I wasn't an only child, and my mother never made it to this country."
"... but when I said he sold me to afford his passage to France, I wasn't telling you the whole truth."

"Like so many little boys growing up, my father was my hero. A dashing rogue, a secret aristocrat hiding away with my mother in the distant mountains of a tropical paradise. He sacrificed so much, to give me everything."
Together, you walk through the open gates. Off, in one corner, you see a family gathered together for a funeral. You keep your distance from them, and in return they pay you no mind.
"I've never been here before."
Taking a deep breath, he gestures to the cemetary gate nearby. "This... is where my father is buried."
"I see you chose to observe me before deciding to engage. I can certainly respect that. I admit, I would have done the same in your position. My letter wasn't as clear as it should have been."
(You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
"Ah, you're here! I'm so glad you came." He admits, with no small amount of relief.
Seeing no other way to get his attention, you playfully tap him on the shoulder.
He looks up at you and approaches. His face wearing the same stony expression of concern.
(You have gained a little credibility)
With his powerful strides, he still looks ever the man of action, even when he's worried. You feel as if you understand him a little better.
Hanging back, you watch him for a while. He paces back and forth in the street like a caged tiger, wearing an expression of deep concern.
You walk up to him with no hesitation, but he has still yet to notice you.
You spot Alexandre before he sees you. He looks pensive.

You draw your shawl a little closer as you're buffetted by another gust of wind. Checking the notes in your journal, you see that you're close to the graveyard where Alexandre wanted to meet you. However, you still have no idea what you're really here for.
"Have you tried to go back for them, to free them?"
"All in all, it was rather morbid, to be honest."
"Absolutely! It was a lovely evening."

Assets/Resources/Incidents/Ludovico - Ep: True to his word, the captain casts off in three minutes. Just like that, it starts to leave Paris behind.
(You have gained quite a bit of credibility)

The dock is awash in murmurs as the assembled crowd tries to understand what they just bore witness to. Tensing up, waiting for the sudden backlash, you realize that the people around you think that you must be an extremely loyal and devout Christian, in order to get a priest to react this way.
"I'll pray for you, every day!"
There's a hesitation in his voice, as he realizes that the entire dock is watching you both. He chooses his next words carefully.
"You're the greatest blessing I've ever had!"
"Yvette! Please stay safe! You're the best woman I've ever met!"
As the boat starts to leave, you're about to turn and head home, until you see Ludovico run to the back of the boat. He starts shouting, loud enough for everyone to hear.
True to his word, the captain casts off in three minutes, and soon it starts to leave Paris behind.
With a downcast gaze, he boards his boat.
"This is it. Addio, Yvette."
You wonder to yourself, is this something lost, or is this just another reason to make sure you survive?

You stay on the dock for a while, and watch his boat disappear into the distance. Part of you wants to watch him for as long as you can, and another part of you simply isn't ready for the trials of getting home through all of this chaos.

"Attention!" Shouts the captain of Ludovico's boat above the din of the crowd. "We're getting ready to cast off. Those who are not on this vessel in three minutes will be left behind." He says with the finality of someone who has actually abandoned passengers before.
"I love you." He says, one last time before boarding his boat.
"This is it. Arrivederci, Yvette."
You stop for a moment, not because you want to, but because you both need to beathe in order to live.

"Attention!" Shouts the captain of Ludovico's boat above the din of the crowd. "We're getting ready to cast off. Those who are not on this vessel in three minutes will be left behind." He says with the finality of someone who has actually abandoned passengers before.
(You have lost some peril)
It isn't a painful delusion, because you both know it isn't real. You feel at peace. You feel some of the danger of the last few days slip away, and gain a sort of clarity.
You kiss with that passion which can only come from desperation. You drink deep of each other, unsure if this will be your last chance to ever do so.

The two of you sit on a the edge of the dock together. You laugh and joke, you talk about which books you've been reading recently. Together, you pretend that nothing is ever going to change.

You pretend as if this moment will last forever.
Unable to restrain yourself further, you grab Ludovico by the wrist and lead him behind a nearby building for one last embrace.
"I guess, this is goodbye."
However, his joy quickly fades, as he remembers what you're both here to do.
He pushes through the crowd to get to you. "Yvette! I'm so glad you came. You have no idea how much this means to me."
(You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
You spot Ludovico walking down from a gangplank, and peering into the crowd. When he spots you, his face blossoms into an exuberant smile.

Finally, you make it to the docks. Instead of the normal bevy of merchant vessels, you can only see barges taking on people, most of them laden with as many of their world possessions as possible. The barges will likely take these peopel via the river to a proper port city. Most people with a desire to leave Paris, and the means to do so, are leaving France altogether.

You wonder if they have the right idea.
You've already lost a lot of time from having to double back and find new routes. It looks like new barricades are going up every day, and the streets simply don't feel safe anymore.
You hurry south through the city, trying to make sure that you make it to the docks in time.
"This isn't 'goodbye'. Just 'see you soon'."
<Kiss him>
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Ludovico's Cl: You stop to think about this new information. Marcelle is a wealthy aristocrat, but her fortune appears to be younger than she claims. It seems like this knowledge could be useful, but you’ll have to dig deeper first.
“Ciao, madame.” Ludovico says before leaving.

“Honestly, it’s been a nice change of pace. Normally I just spend a lot of time listening to bishops and writing letters back to the Vatican. This has me out and about, enjoying Paris, and getting a feel for its people.”
“Haha! Sorry, I’ve always wanted to say something like that.”

“While I must go, remember that all of this is speculation. If you want to use any of this information against Marcelle, you’ll need indisputable proof of whatever lies or wrongdoing she’s engaged in, or it’ll simply be your word against hers. Still, I will pray for your success.”
You’re not sure if Ludovico helping you exact your revenge could really be classified as ‘the right thing’, but you’re not going to complain.

Ludovico leans in close and whispers in your ear, his voice barely audible. “Madame, Rome chose me as their eyes and ears in France. You didn’t think that they’d sent someone who’s never gotten their hands dirty, did you?”
“Think nothing of it madame, I’m just trying to do the right thing.”
“It feels like Marcelle is hiding something, and it has to do with her money.”

“Thirty years is a long time for most people, yes, but compared to most aristocratic families, that’s barely the blink of an eye. From the mindset of the clergy, it’s even less. There are churches in France that are over 1,000 years old. Why would her family pretend their fortune is older than it really is?”

“Strangely enough, the moment I actually started looking into Marcelle’s wealth and position, something didn’t feel right. She claims that her storied family fortune comes from a series of wise investments, so I started paying visits and offering blessings to some of her family’s known business partners. In that whole time, I couldn’t find evidence that any of her family’s investments were older than thirty years or so.”

“... is a very good point,” he admits with a defeated sigh. You can tell that he was quite enjoying this air of intrigue, but you’d rather have some quick results. Ludovico sits down next to you and composes himself.

“I know I’ve already said this before, but I still want to tell you that I’m sorry for everything that happened to you. From what I know, Marcelle’s always had a penchant for being vindictive. This, combined with her wealth and position, makes her a force to be reckoned with.”

"I'm so glad to see you. Armand, that ambitious little thing, has told me so much about you. In fact, I'd say that he's quite infatuated with you. A common girl like yourself... you're so lucky!"

She advances on you, close enough to feel the heat of her breath. “Let me be clear. You and your grasping fiance are not guests in my home, nor will you ever be. I invited him here so I could express my displeasure to him in person.”
She pauses before speaking to you in a whisper loud enough for the entire room to hear. “Don’t worry, I don’t expect you to understand this.”
“but now, I now have his cast off fiancee, who even had the audacity to lie to my face!”

“Nobody’s heard from your cowardly fiance in weeks, which is especially surprising, since he could never stop pestering his betters.” The crowd, which only seems to be growing, murmurs in agreement. “In fact, it’s been so long that I thought I was rid of him once and for all…”
“I mean, that’s because we both know Armand’s not sick.”
“Well I’m so glad you’re here, and I’m sure that he’ll be well soon.”
"Oh really, he insisted?" Marcelle trills and her dog yips happily.
"Trying to look like us? Act like us? Stop. You're just embarassing yourself."
“Now leave my estate, and never show your face here again.”

“Now pay attention, because I’d hate for you to miss the point. If you should ever find your wandering Armand, tell him that he is an unwelcome, conniving weasel. In fact, both of you should go back to your petty little village, and leave Paris to your superiors.”

Marcelle studies your face intently for a moment and her voice suddenly fills with concern. “Oh, you poor girl, don’t look so hurt! Think of this as educational. You don’t belong in Paris, the same way that a stray cat doesn’t belong in that dress.” She gestures dismissively at your finery.
A small cheer rings up from the crowd.

“Please pay attention, because I hate repeating myself. Your Armand is gone, off somewhere on another one of his foolish little political endeavors. However, if you should ever find him, tell him that he is an impudent weasel, who should go back to whatever backwater he crawled out of, and leave the running of this country to his superiors.”

“Your Armand is a conniving, impish, opportunist who sullies the good name of the entire nobility just by being alive. The only reason he even chose a common girl like you to be his wife, is because any lady of good breeding would see him for the weasel that he is.”
“but now, I have this commoner, who doesn’t know her place either!”
“Now, not only do I find out that he’s a coward, who’s fled his fiancee, and his responsibilities…”

“Armand, that ambitious little rat, was always reaching above his station. His audacity truly knew no bounds.” Her eyes are focused on you, but she’s speaking to the crowd, who seem to whisper in agreement. Even the dog regards you with malice.
“After all, you’ve already helped me!”

For a moment, the crowd hushes. You seem to have struck a nerve. Even the dog looks a little undone. “I suppose that when cornered, even a rat will think it’s a lion,” Marcelle whispers, her voice like ice.

Marcelle pauses to pet her dog. “I don’t know where he is. In fact, it’s a shame that Armand’s already scurried off somewhere. I was really hoping to tell him this to his face, but then again, he always was so good at disappointing people. You’ll have to do.”
“Why? While those craven nationalists in their dingy salons like to hide behind their pamphlets and newsletters, people of quality must be brave enough to denounce our enemies in person.”
“Yet here you are, with a fresh set of nuisances. Does this ever end?”

“I guess it makes sense that you’re here. Armand could never stop pestering his betters, so it feels rather appropriate that, even when sick, he’d send his peasant fiance to do it for him.” The crowd, which only seems to be growing, murmurs in agreement. “In fact, I almost thought I was rid of him once and for all…”
“I mean, I was hoping he’d show his face here, but you’ll do.”

Marcelle stares at you, concerned and shocked. “You don’t know where he is, and yet you still came to this little event of mine?” She gestures a free hand at the most splendid party you’ve ever seen in your life. “That is so kind of you, of course I’ll help!”

“That is so sweet of him!” Marcelle trills and her dog yips happily. “You’ve barely arrived from the country and he still wants you to meet all the people he’s been so fortunate to associate with. It’s very kind of you to represent him like this, and I’m sure that he’ll be well soon.”
“Where is Armand, by the way?”
A murmur of interest washes through the crowd, and you can feel their eyes focus on you.
Her voice raises in volume imperceptibly, but it’s enough to draw the attention of the large crowd in the room. “Everyone, this is Yvette, Armand’s fiancee!”

You nearly mistake the woman standing in front of you for some kind of walking confection. A pampered dog lounges in her arms. “I don’t believe we had the chance to properly introduce ourselves. I am Viscountess Marcelle de Foix.”
“I may be audacious, but at least I know how to treat my guests.”
“I’m guessing this means you don’t know where he is, either?”
“...why did you invite Armand here?”
“Poor Armand is ill at the moment, but he just insisted that I attend your party.”
“I may be a commoner, but at least I know how to treat my guests.”
“I’m guessing this means you don’t know where he is?”
“...why did you invite Armand here?”
“Do you always bemoan every ‘nuisance’ you send a handwritten invitation to?”
“...why did you invite Armand here?”
“That’s actually what I was hoping to find out. Do you know where I could find him?”

“Your cowardly fiance could have spent his time doing something useful, like echoing the views of his betters. Instead he chose to waste our time with calls to consider lesser, erroneous perspectives. We don’t need to tolerate this kind of intellectual and moral weakness. Both of you should do the right thing and skulk back to wherever you came from, in silence.”
“Of course, it’s a shame your loyalty is anchored to such mediocrity, but still...”

“Your loyalty to Armand is commendable, and exactly the sort of thing we’re striving to bring to this troubled nation of ours.”

A small cheer goes up from some of the crowd.

“It’s been weeks since anyone’s heard from the Baron de Marbo. Originally, I’d taken it as a blessing that we no longer had to deal with his ignorant and uninformed declarations. However, now I find myself face to face with his fiancee, who isn’t just ignorant, but a liar!”
“Unless, of course, he’s not actually sick.”

Maximin chuckles, “Of course, this gathering is more of a salon than a party, but I can see why you would be confused.” He reaches out and pats your hand. “Please don’t be embarrassed, I’m sure Armand will be able to explain the differences later, when he’s feeling better.”

"I must say that I’m surprised that Armand thinks so highly of true, revolutionary minds.” Murmurs of appreciation and agreement ripple through the crowd, but are quickly hushed by other guests, who are also pretending that they’re not listening in.

“Tell your Baron de Marbo to stay in his sick bed. It is a blessing for all of France that we no longer have to deal with his ignorant and uninformed declarations.” He emphasizes his point by slapping one of his pamphlets against his thigh. “Who knows? Perhaps if the two of you read enough, you might be able to stop embarrassing yourselves.”
“You’ve lost him?” Maximin asks, a sudden note of confusion marring his features. “And you came here?”
"Oh, really?"
“I’ve been told that Armand is unable to join us tonight. What has delayed him?”

“Ah, you must be Madame Decaux! I’m not sure if Armand spoke of me, I am Baron Maximin de Termes.” Right as he focuses his attention on you, you can feel everyone in the room watching you out of the corners of their eyes. His opinion must carry a great deal of weight.
“Titles don’t elevate us above consequences. Now, leave my house and never return.”
“You are a fool for believing that, and he is a fool for loving you.”
“Like a barnacle... or a leech.”

“Our associations reflect our character, and you have chosen to associate yourself with an ignorant boor who drags at the heels of true progress in France. I can only assume that you are a craven opportunist who thought that marrying into a title would provide an easy path above her peers. That your life would be easy, if you just found the right person to latch onto.”
“You are wrong.”
He takes a step towards you, and you can see that his eyes are filled with hate. “Now still your childish tongue. The adults are talking.”

The Baron takes a breath to recompose himself and snort derisively. “Well actually, if you’d taken the time to read any of the materials I just gave you, then you’d know that calls for civility are the enemy of progress.”

“And you…” he continues “I don’t need to investigate you any further to know that you are cut from the same wretched cloth.” 

The room is quiet enough to hear a pin drop.

“The only reason I even invited him was to save myself the time of authoring a pamphlet denouncing him.” Maximin snorts “He, and his regressive calls for moderation and discussion. In a time of such turmoil in our country, only decisive action has any meaning. To believe otherwise is to be a coward, and a bootlick to the enemies of the people.”
Maximin’s voice drops low, to a growl barely above a whisper, “Before you speak, I already know what you’re thinking. That somehow, you don’t deserve this…”

“Calls for moderation in our time of crisis can only be seen as treasonous to the people of France. He is an enemy of the revolution, an enemy of the common people of France, and an enemy of mine. The only thing he can do to atone for his miserable views is to take you, and return to the backwards obscurity from whence he came!”
Maximin narrows his eyes until they’re barely more than slits. “In fact, you can practice this virtue now and make sure that he hears this, should you manage to find him.”
You hear a collective intake of breath from the gawking crowd. Maximin seems on the verge of a retort, but he stutters for a moment instead.
“I do not know where he has skulked off to, nor am I inclined to find him.”

“I invited your dullard fiance in order to denounce him and his views. People as uninformed as himself should not waste their time clouding discussions with their tiresome ignorance. They’re better served by repeating the words of their more revolutionary peers.”
“If he’s lost then it means we no longer have to entertain his invalid opinions.”

With a flood of realization he laughs “Oh, but of course! You’re just here, at my salon, to find your Armand! I thought you were here for our enlightened discourse but… no, this makes much more sense.”
The crowd is no longer making a secret of observing your conversation. They’re gawking.
“In fact, when you do that, I have a message for him. Write this down, if you can.”

Maximin chuckles, “Of course, this gathering is more of a salon than a party, but I can see why you would be confused.” He reaches out and pats your hand. “Please don’t be embarrassed, I’m sure Armand will be able to explain the differences later, when he’s feeling better.”

“That’s fantastic to hear! I’m surprised that Armand thinks so highly of true, revolutionary minds.” Murmurs of appreciation and agreement ripple through the crowd, but are quickly hushed by other guests, who are also pretending that they’re not listening in.
Maximin pauses, his eyes sweeping the room for a moment. “But please, I must trouble you with a question of my own.”

“In fact, you may both find these useful!” He grabs a jumbled stack of political pamphlets off of his desk and hands them to you. “Discourse moves so rapidly after all, and I would hate for the two of you to have any trouble keeping up.”

A few voices in the crowd murmur in approval.

“It’s great to meet the woman Armand spoke so much of. He said more about you than he did the state of the nation, and you know much he loves that.” Maximin smiles and offers a knowing wink. “Now that I’ve seen you, I can see why he had such muddled priorities.”

“But please, let us dispense with titles, you may call me Maximin!”

The crowd chuckles, and you can’t help but be surprised by this noble’s informality. This would be downright scandalous in any other circle. The conversations in the various corners of the room die down as people strain to hear your exchange with Maximin.

You notice a tall, thin man dressed in somber, serious colors. The way people are clustered around him, you get the feeling that he’s quite important. He glances up from his current conversation, politely excuses himself, and approaches you.
"I actually don't know, Maximin. I don't even know where he is."
"I'm sorry, but Armand has taken ill. Still, he said that I just had to attend your party."
“Are you even listening to yourself? Because I am, and I wish I wasn’t.”
"You don't know where he is either, then?"
"...if he was so mediocre, why did you invite him?"
“I don’t need your pamphlets to know that you’re being a presumptuous boor.”
"...why invite Armand if you disliked him so?"

He rubs his chin thoughtfully. "Perhaps, you're right. Most of their ranks are made of desperate common men, and they're a group founded in stern discipline. We'd just need to convince them to fight for a righteous cause, instead of a tyrannical one."

After a long pause, he rubs his chin thoughtfully. "Perhaps, you're right. While the priests in the cities are self centered and corrupt, the ones in the country-side might care about our cause. They're also experienced in rousing the common people to action."
He looks at you askance. "The Bourgeoisie? You really think I should reach out to those money-hungry pigs?"
He looks at you askance. "The Military? You really think I should reach out to the King's personal attack dogs?"
He looks at you askance. "The Church? You really think I should reach out to those agents of a foreign monarch, who support the king, and strut about like petty nobles?"
"What do you think? Who should we reach out to?"

"Of course, while I understand the value of forming alliances, I also find the whole affair distasteful. I can't bring myself to begin the kinds of intrigues that have turned the King's courts into a festering pit of petty schemes."
"In fact, those same people have placed me in charge of secretly reaching out to some of the other causes in the city, to build alliances on behalf of the Revolution."
After taking a moment to regain his calm, Antoine turns to you and says, "Did you know some of our fellow revolutionaries heard about our direct action with the posters? They called it inspiring."
He pauses for a while, searching his memories. "It's funny. You're the first person I've told this story to, who cared about how she felt."
"Of course, I never blamed her. I know how much it must have hurt, which only made my anger worse."
"Why are we so content to dine on the table scraps of powerful, selfish men? Why are we so content to let them carve up our lives?"
"It wasn't just my romances being foiled, or someone I loved being hurt, it was the thought that this was happening all over France. That it's still happening every single day."
"While I was locked in a reformatory, I had a lot of time to think about what, exactly, made me so angry."
"It was a good life for a few days before I was arrested." He says wistfully. "The kind of freedom I needed to clear my head. To align my principles."
"When I came home, I was greeted by something else entirely."
"So excited." He says again, taking a swig from the small bottle of liquor he's been nursing throughout the night.
"I stole my family's silver, a pair of pistols, and rode for Paris."
"Of course, I went nearly mad with rage. So, I did what any full blooded man in my situation would do."

Assets/Resources/Incidents/Pierre's Info: At the mention of God, Pierre makes the sign of the cross, but you’re pretty sure he did it backwards. “Adieu madame, and may our paths cross again!”
Pierre nods and grins, “But, of course, Madame! It is merely business, but I still hope it is good business. Adieu, madame!”
Pierre puts down his snuff box and favors you with a deep and theatrical bow. “Now you flatter me madame. Bone chance madame, and may God see fit to reunite you with your Armand in great haste.”
“I like to think we’ve made good business partners, non?”
“But please, enough about such ignoble matters, you are here to learn of your fiance, non?”
While the empty liquor bottles laying on the ground make you doubt his honesty a little, you get the feeling that he isn’t going to budge on this.

He gestures to his dilapidated and stained office. “However, while the pursuit of truth may make a man virtuous, it does not make him wealthy. The coins I give are all I can spare, as I need all that remains to keep the wheels of my press turning.”

Pierre scowls at you for a fraction of a second, before breaking out into a wide and almost-sympathetic grin. “Madame, but if only I could! I would pay for your gracious insights with bars of silver, and fistfuls of rubies, as that is what they are worth!”
“Merci beaucoups, madame…” he sighs, pausing to inhale a heavy pinch of snuff. “But please, enough about my troubles, you are here to learn of your fiance, non?”
“I needed you because most of my sources have taken their business to other… less esteemed publications.”

“I can’t just print gossip that’s been sold to everyone else. My readers expect something unique in these pages, not the same unoriginal tripe bandied about in those… lesser papers.”

You find yourself slightly taken aback by the sincerity in Pierre’s voice.

“Journals like my own have always existed in one… unofficial capacity or another, but with the end of royal censorship, new papers are opening every day! The competition for readership, and for new information, has become ridiculous!” Pierre throws up his hands in exasperation.

He hands you the paper, it’s an address. “The Guet Royal raided the studio a month ago and arrested everyone there. While supporting the king is certainly not a crime, some of this talk was getting violent, which the Crown can’t risk in times like this. Ever since then, the place has been abandoned. Go there, and you might find something that leads you to your Armand.”

“There’s a studio in the seventh arrondissement where he and some like minded individuals preferred to discuss the proper course for the country. Painters in the front, planning in the back.” Pierre starts scribbling on a piece of paper.

“Now, before you leave madame, I hope that you do not forget about me and my humble paper. I still find your social insights valuable, and I’m stilling willing to pay for anything you can bring to me.”

He hands you the paper, it’s an address. “The Guet Royal raided the studio a month ago and arrested everyone there. The Crown looks down on that kind of thinking, after all. Ever since then, the place has been abandoned. Go there, and you might find something that leads you to your Armand.”
“These compatriots of his were royalists, but a more… dedicated kind. They felt that any kind of dissent was a violation of natural law, that sort of thing…”

“There’s a studio in the seventh arrondissement where he and some like minded individuals preferred to discuss their plans for the country. Painters in the front, planning in the back.” Pierre starts scribbling on a piece of paper.

“To put it simply, these compatriots of his are extreme nationalists. They don’t just want tax reform, they don’t just want a constitution, they want bigger changes for France, and don’t care what it takes to accomplish it.”
Pierre sighs and mops the sweat from his brow with a severely stained handkerchief. “To be honest madame, I am in a bit of a tough situation.”

Pierre claps his hands together in delight, “Madame, it appears that you have done me a great service! With all of this gossip together, I can finally launch my most comprehensive social piece yet!”

Turning around, you see two women, one of them is obviously deep in their cups. The other appears to be trying to prevent her friend from embarassing themselves too much. 

"Sorry about the stain, we were just leaving." The sober one apologizes half-heartedly.

Looking down, you see an enormous wine stain down your front.

(Your outfit has lost some novelty)

Suddenly, you feel someone barge into you, sending you reeling a few steps. While you manage to catch your balance on a nearby table, your chest feels wet, and your wineglass now appears to be empty.

Oh no.

Relaxing at the party, you feel more comfortable with your new life than before. Sipping from your recently acquired glass of wine, you notice a fresh batch of hors d'oeuvres being brought out from the kitchen.

This feels right. You could get used to this.
"That's a good question. Why did you stop? Embarassments like you belong outside." <Peril Icon>
"It's alright, you're free to go when I get an apology." <Credibility Check Icon>
"Pardon, I'm not mad, can you just help me blot this stain before it sets?"
Assets/Resources/Incidents/Stranger and: After a brief pause, Camille ventures “Madame, if I may ask, can I have the kitchen to myself? I’d like to start making your lunch.”
“That’s all I can remember madame. Now… if I may ask, can I have the kitchen to myself? I’d like to start making your lunch.”
You look down at the green ink used the write the note to Armand. A connection?

“However...” Camille straightens up, tapping her finger on her chin. “There was a woman who came by more frequently than the other guests. She had brown hair, and a scar on her chin.
I remember her because she always wore a silver necklace, with the prettiest emerald in the center of it.
“Madame, what would you like me to do?”
“Understood madame!” Camille replies cheerily. “Armand required his privacy as well, it’s no wonder the two of you were engaged.”
“I never asked anyone’s names, madame.” Camille admits, looking downcast. “So many of Monsieur Armand’s guests valued their privacy, that I wanted to give them a polite amount space.”
“Madame, what’s going on?”

Camille looks utterly shocked when you press the money into her hands. “Madame I can’t possibly take this, it’s too much, it’s too…” she trails off as she evaluates your expression, and composes herself a moment later.

(You have given away 25 Livres!)

“Know about what?” Camille asks, glancing between you and the bag of coins in your hands. “Was that Monsieur Armand’s? Why would he leave money in the house?”

She seems to be even more confused by all of this than you are.
“I was just about to start making lunch…” Camille says, pointing awkwardly at the stove.
You look up from your sudden windfall to see Camille standing in the doorway to the kitchen. Her eyes are darting between you and the box in confusion.

You look inside the bag… that’s a lot of coins.

(You have gained 100 Livres!)
Inside the box you find a magnetic compass, a map of Paris with notes concerning when the guards change at every one of the city gates, and a leather bag heavy with coins.
You pull up the floorboards and fish around in the dark until you find a small wooden box, held shut by a padlock. You open it with the key you found behind the painting.

Heading downstairs, you walk into the kitchen. It’s clean but cramped, and Camille keeps it well stocked with fresh produce. You find the stove, made of dark iron and standing on a set of clawed feet. 

Alone, on your hands and knees, you feel around until you find a set of loose floorboards.

You turn over the letter and find no additional writing, no additional context or explanation. 

Who is Marie-Jeanne? How long has Armand known her for? Is she one of the people he’d been writing back home?

‘Your partner in conspiracy,

Marie-Jeanne’

‘If fortune turns against us, then I want you to flee Paris entirely. I know you’ve objected to the idea before, but it’s the only way for you to stay safe. To aid in this, I’ve secreted a package under the loose floorboards beneath your stove. This key will open it.’

You look at the key. It’s still here, so Armand never received the note.

‘Dear Armand,

I will always appreciate your commitment to our cause, and I know France will be better for it. However, our chance of being caught grows with every passing day. I will not waste ink painting terrible pictures of the consequences, as you are already familiar with them.’
Back home, you finally pull the note and key out from under your stays. Unfamiliar handwriting written in rich, emerald ink.
“Nothing yet, Camille. Nothing yet.”
“Who was Marie-Jeanne? How well did she know Armand?”
“Nothing yet, Camille. Nothing yet.”
“Who was Marie-Jeanne? How well did she know Armand?”
“Looks like we both got lucky today.” (-25 Livre)
“Camille, did you know about this?”
(Château de Vincennes is now available to visit in the Paris map)
With that, he turns from you and strolls away, towards the other party guests.
He bends low and kisses the back of your hand. "I'm sorry, but I should step away, before anyone gets suspicious. We have to keep this secret, for now."
"I don't exactly what you can do for him, but it will do great things for the Revolution if we can show people that we defend those who aid us."
With dismissive gesture, he turns from you and stalks away, back towards the other party guests.

He takes a few moments explaining where Château de Vincennes is, and everything you'd need to know about the location. It used to be a fortress, but one half of it was converted into a prison, and the other half into a nunnery. Usually, it's used to hold criminals who the Crown consider a real threat, but doesn't want to abuse, yet.
(You have gained some favor with Antoine)
"Ugh... if you can't help then I'll find someone who can."
(You have lost some favor with Antoine)
"Really, that's where you draw your line?" He asks, incredulous. "This man helped us. We should help him."
"I knew I could count on you."
"Can you try to help him?"
"This man, Monsieur Clet, he has taken risks for us. It's time for us to repay the favor."
"Normally, I would do something myself, but I have reason to believe the archers have been told to keep an eye on me." He continues, eyeing certain guests at the party suspiciously.

"While we may have gotten away unscathed, it appears that the printmaker who made the posters wasn't so lucky. One of his apprentices betrayed him to the archers, and now our friend is imprisoned in Château de Vincennes, and awaiting a very one-sided trial."
"Do you remember those posters we put up?"
(You have gained a little credibility)
(You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
(You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
He sighs and nods. "Your caution is understandable."
He pauses to glower at you. "Fine, let me explain the problem first."
"Fantastique!" He replies with a wolfish grin.
"Yvette, something dire has happened, and there is something I will need you to do." He says in a low voice.
He gently takes you by the elbow and leads you to a corner of the room, away from everyone else.
As you walk around the party, sipping your wine, you notice Antoine is walking directly towards you. He look concerned.
"Antoine, I'm not ready to commit crimes for a man I've never met."
"For liberty? I'll see what I can do."
"What, exactly, do you need me to do?"
"Excuse me? I don't work for you, Antoine."
"Just tell me the problem, and I'll handle the rest."

Assets/Resources/Incidents/The Abandoned: New Moment
New Moment
You can’t help but grin with satisfaction. This is the lead you were looking for.

You turn the painting back and forth looking for more details, until you hear something metallic shift. Flipping the painting over, you find a note tucked into the frame on the back of painting, along with a key. You don’t recognize the handwriting, but decide against taking the time to read the note now, while illegally trespassing in a condemned building. You carefully fold the note around the key and secret it under your stays.

Armand’s smiling face is looking back at you from the picture, a glass raised in mid toast, and a quill in his free hand. On one side of him is a man you remember from your last night together with Armand. The man is named Isaac. On the other side of him, is a young woman, with strawberry blonde hair, who you’ve never seen before. Her hand is on his shoulder.

It’s a dining scene, done in a reflected perspective intended to make the actual room feel larger than it really is. All the men and women in the picture are laughing, clinking glasses and looking merry. 

Even Armand.
GUET ROYAL TELEGRAPH
The rest of the unburned scraps look too small or unclear to provide you with any additional information.
‘-and de Marbo’, written in familiar handwriting on a fragment of paper. Armand was here, perhaps in this very room. Maybe there’s something else connected to him nearby.

You pick through the ashes, finding fragments of leather and scraps of unburned paper. The writing on the paper is handwritten, not printed. It looks like a list of names. A membership list?

That’s when you spot it.
GUET ROYAL TELEGRAPH
You find nothing else of value under the circular table.
GUET ROYAL TELEGRAPH
While you’re sure this reading list is insightful, it won’t bring you closer to finding Armand.

Eventually, you can deduce a meaning from the scratchings. All the notes are suggested readings, various books and pamphlets. They seem to cover a broad range of texts related to religious or political theory. The authors extend from France to the rest of the continent, and even the Americas.

Stepping over the ash in front of the fireplace, you gingerly take the painting off of its hook and examine it closely. It’s not as carefully detailed as some of the others in the building, but there’s a certain joyful energy to it. Whoever painted this genuinely enjoyed making it.

You bend down carefully, making sure you don’t kneel in the large swath of ashes in front of the fireplace. A cold breeze blows at your back and you look up at the charred hole in the roof of the building. This fire must have gotten large enough to set a portion of the ceiling ablaze. It’s a miracle this building is still standing at all.

Whoever started this fire didn’t have time to do things properly, they just needed something burned.
You scan the room, deciding what to investigate.
No. Wait. It’s just terrible handwriting.

You find a small scattering of coins. It appears that, at some point in the chaos, someone must have dropped their coin purse, and nobody noticed it. It doesn’t bring you closer to Armand, but you’ll never turn down free coin.

(You’ve gained +6 Livre!)
You bend down to investigate under the table, trying to find what caught the light of your lantern and glimmered at you from the dark.
You lean close to the notes on the wall, and squint to read them. None of them make any sense, as if they were written in another language, or some kind of code.
What are you going to investigate?

Inside, the back room is cramped, mostly occupied by a circular table with some small chairs. Various notes are pinned to the wall, and as you shine your lantern about, you notice a slight glimmer under the table.
GUET ROYAL TELEGRAPH
You feel like you’ve learned everything you can from the paintings in this room.
Looking at the paintings, you feel like you’ve learned something about the artists here, but nothing useful about Armand. You’ll have to search somewhere he would have spent a lot of time in.

The stairs creak underneath your feet as you make your way to the second floor. The long table and scattered cutlery suggests that it was used as a dining area. A small fireplace occupies one side of the room, with a wide swath of ash spilling out of the fireplace and onto the floor. Above the fireplace itself, a painting hangs on the mantle.

The entrance to the back room isn’t obvious and if Pierre hadn’t told you about it earlier, you might have mistaken it for a closet door. When you go to open the door, you notice that the latch has been torn off. Probably a casualty of the raid.

What are you going to investigate?

Inside, the back room is cramped, mostly occupied by a circular table with some small chairs. Various notes are pinned to the wall, and as you shine your lantern about, you notice a slight glimmer under the table.

The paintings on the wall are all traditional historical pieces, exactly the sort of thing L’Academie exalts as ‘true art’. Judging by the stern faces and repeated images, you’re sure that the paintings are all meant to be some kind of political allegory, but you can’t really tell what of.

The desk by the door is so beautiful that it seems to clash with the rough practicality of the other furniture in the room. All of the drawers have been flung open, and papers have been scattered everywhere.
Scanning the room, you try to determine what you’ll investigate.
“Where should we look?”
Hansel steps in front of you and whispers. “Now that we have a light in here, it’s only a matter of time before someone spots us. I recommend we move quickly, madame.”
Now that you have a little more light, you can see that most of the furniture inside is broken, and enough things are missing to make you wonder how much the Guet Royal seized during their raid.

Inside, the studio is even darker than you would have guessed. Between the boards on the windows, and the lack of lighting in the surrounding street, it’s nearly impossible to pick out any detail smaller than the walls and doors.

You carefully use a flint stowed in the base of your lantern to light it, then muffle most of the light with the hem of your cloak.

The stairs creak underneath your feet as you make your way to the second floor. The long table and scattered cutlery suggests that it was used as a dining area. A small fireplace occupies one side of the room, with a wide swath of ash spilling out of the fireplace and onto the floor. Above the fireplace itself, a painting hangs on the mantle.

The entrance to the back room isn’t obvious and if Pierre hadn’t told you about it earlier, you might have mistaken it for a closet door. When you go to open the door, you notice that the latch has been torn off. Probably a casualty of the raid.
Your time is limited, where do you plan on searching for clues?

Now that you have a little more light, you can see that most of the furniture inside is broken, and enough things are missing to make you wonder how much the Guet Royal seized during their raid. It’s also only a matter of time before someone spots you and comes to investigate.

From your position outside, you peer into the gloom and watch Hansel examine the room for a few moments before he gives a satisfied nod, dropping his hand from his weapon. Returning to the window, he grabs you by the waist, and easily helps you into the building.

He enters the building first, his face frozen in a grim expression that almost makes you feel bad for any dangerous persons you might encounter.

Almost.
You get Hansel’s attention, and he quietly takes down the boards, leaving them in a neat pile by the window to be put back later.

Now that you’re closer, you can see that the door has been nailed shut. Wordlessly, you and Hansel start checking the boards on the windows, seeing if any of them are loose. On the third window, you find one of boards easily gives way, like it’s been pulled out before.

Someone else has been here.

The mercenary crouches down and places his hand on the grip of his sabre. You hike up your skirts, and get ready to follow him. On his signal, you quietly dash across the street together, watching for any movement in the windows as your approach.
When you get to the window, Hansel’s hands emerge from the darkness and grab you by the waist, easily helping you into the building.
After what feels like an eternity, you see his hand emerge from the opened window and motion for you to approach. You hike up your skirts and quietly hurry across the street towards him.

Hansel gazes warily at the building before turning back to you. For a moment he looks like he’s about to object, but your mind is obviously made up. 

“Understood, madame. We go together.”

Eventually, he finds that some of the boards covering one of the windows are loose, quietly pries them off, and easily hops through the window into the building inside. You catch glimpses of him through some of the other windows as he scouts out the darkened interior.

Crouching as low as his sizeable frame will allow, Hansel advances towards the building with his hand firmly on the grip of his sabre. He glances inside the windows and tries the door, which appears to be have been nailed shut.
“Madame, I’d like to inspect the building first. You never know who’s taken up residence in empty places like this.”

Inside, the studio is even darker than you would have guessed. Between the boards on the windows, and the lack of lighting in the surrounding street, it’s nearly impossible to pick out any detail smaller than the walls and doors.

You carefully use a flint stowed in the base of your lantern to light it, then muffle most of the light with the hem of your cloak.

You carefully ease yourself through the window, making sure none of your clothes get caught on any exposed nails. Once inside, you close your eyes for a few moments, so they’ll adjust to the darkness faster.
Gingerly, you take down each of the boards, leaving them in a neat pile by the window to be put back later. Secrets are easier to uncover when nobody knows that you’re looking at all.

Leaning back and craning your neck to examine the roof, you see there’s a hole big enough for you to enter the building through, but you don’t have a ladder, or any way to get up there. For a moment you consider trying to enter the building next door, so you can drop down onto the roof, but it’s better to do this as quickly as possible.

Putting down your unlit lantern, you start checking the boards on the windows, seeing if any of them are loose. On the third window, you find one set of boards easily gives way, like it’s been pulled out before.

Someone else has been here.
You immediately notice that the door’s been nailed shut.
Rather than stand around in the middle of a dark street, you hike up your skirts and hurry across the road to the studio.
Glancing around, you don’t see anyone at all, as if the King’s notice somehow closed the entire street.
Before you can step any further towards the closed building, Hansel steps in front of you.

Rounding a corner, you find yourself on an empty street, looking across the road at the studio. The windows of the small, two storey building have been boarded up, and there’s a charred hole in the roof. A sign nailed to the door reads ‘Closed! On orders of the King.’

Rounding a corner, you find yourself on an empty street, looking across the road at the studio. The windows of the small, two storey building have been boarded up, and there’s a charred hole in the roof. A sign nailed to the door reads ‘Closed! On orders of the King.’

Winding your way through the streets of the 7th Arrondissement, you can’t help but think about how out of the way this place would have been for Armand. Yet, Pierre said that he was still a regular visitor. Despite yourself, you find your heart beating faster and faster as you get closer to the abandoned studio.

You waited for sunset before you headed out, as it feels like these sort of things are better done under the cover of darkness. However, everything still feels too bright. Every hanging lantern, every candle-lit window, feels like an eye staring down at you.

Tugging on the edges of your hood to make sure your face is hidden from view, you glance down again at the hastily scribbled address Pierre gave you in his office. In addition to your regular traveling clothes, you have a small bag hanging off of your shoulder, and a portable lantern with a flint.

The front of the building is the painting studio, the floors spattered with pigments, and still littered with the scraps of various art supplies. An ornate desk sits in the front of the room, near the door, with papers scattered all around it. A few finished canvases still remain on the walls, though it looks like a lot of the others were either seized or destroyed.

Assets/Resources/Incidents/The Cardinal: (You have acquired some gossip. This will be useful later.)
(You have lost some credibility)
(You have gained a little peril)
(You have acquired some gossip. This will be useful later.)

The two of them disappear to a more secluded section of the party, watching you carefully all the while. 

You have a feeling they didn’t believe you.

“Well, if you did actually grow up there, you must be more familiar with the facts than us.” The older man demures, already pulling his friend away by the elbow. “We would hate to supply you with any misinformation.”

He puts a strong emphasis on the word ‘supply’.

The younger man examines you carefully before he says “That’s quite an unusual accent you have, for someone who grew up in Grenoble.”

Your mind races, and you’re not sure if you can remember what a Grenoble accent even sounds like.
"I can understand why, madame. It was grizzly enough that the church didnt make any official announcements. The archbishops funeral was closed casket because-"

During your conversation, you manage to get a few more details about the time of death, who discovered the body, and more. This is exactly what you were hoping for. A rumor, by itself, isn’t of any consequence. Specific details add an air of truthfulness which is necessary for quality gossip. This should be valuable to someone.

“I suppose he’s right.” The younger man admits. “What’s most important is that archbishop’s death was a suicide, and this made the church extremely uncomfortable. This is why they were so quiet about his passing.”
You continue your hushed conversation with the two men, and manage to tease out a few more specifics. The three of you eventually go your separate ways.
This is exactly the level of detail you were hoping for. A rumor, by itself, isn’t of any consequence. Gruesome details, on the other hand, make for fine gossip. This should be valuable to someone.

“The archbishop of Grenoble shot himself.” The younger man says flatly. “It was a suicide, and a particularly gruesome one at that. That’s why he was in a closed casket instead of being laid out properly. It was also why the church was so unwilling to divulge the details of his death.”
“Don’t worry, such details are unnecessary to understanding the bigger picture.” The older man says in an a patronizing tone.
After a long pause, the older man relents. “Fine, if you must know...”
“I would not want to offend the madame’s sensibilities with such dreadful details.”
The older guest stops his friend mid sentence. “I’m not sure if we should continue.”

The two of them disappear to a more secluded section of the party, watching you carefully all the while. 

You have a feeling that you’ll be watched more closely from now on.
Before you can answer, his older friend chimes in. “Perhaps we should take our conversation elsewhere. I doubt that we’ll find any privacy here.”

You hear a throat clear.

“Can we help you, madame?” The younger man asks you, with a suspicious scowl.
However, this does give you the level of detail you were hoping for. A rumor, by itself isn’t valuable. Details, on the other hand, make for fine gossip. This should be valuable to someone.

“Well that would certainly explain why it was a closed casket affair. There mustn’t have been much of him left, after that.” 

Your mind conjures up a gruesome image, entirely against your will, and you wretch internally at it.
“I hear that he loaded two bullets in his pistol before he… did it.”
“For a many of the cloth to commit the cardinal sin? It is the only explanation.”
“He must have felt some guilt for everything that happened.” The older man ventures.

You decide against engaging them in conversation, or listening in. While it’s nice to have some reliable gossip, you don’t need it that badly right now. Instead, you spend some time wandering about the party, sipping at your wine, taking in the sights and the sounds.

The men are speaking to each other in low voices, and it’s difficult to hear them over the din of the party. You edge a little closer to listen to them, pretending to scan the party as if you were looking for a friend that got lost in the crowd.
They turn, noticing you for the first time.
If you could learn more, this might be some truly valuable gossip.

“That he'd killed himself after the riots. Yes, even I found that distressing.”

You’d heard that too, but it was only a rumor. The Church never confirmed this, but why would they?
The older man replies wearily “Agreed, and the bloodshed was monstrous. Did you hear about their Bishop?”

The younger one sighs, and gestures to the crowd with his wine glass. “Everyone’s talking about reforming the estates as if it’s going to be as simple as making a request. Does nobody remember what happened in Grenoble? They sent soldiers into that town just for trying to hold a meeting.”
You happen upon a pair of men whispering in a corner together. They’re trying to look as happy and engaged as the other guests, but they’re movements are too stiff. They seem concerned.
“Perhaps you are right. It may be too much for me.”
“Please monsieur, I need to know.”
<Leave them alone>
<Eavesdrop>
“Pardon monsieurs, but I grew up in Grenoble and I never found out what happened. Do you know?”
Assets/Resources/Incidents/The Eyes of S: None of hte other guests have no context for this display of fury. All they know is that you were willing to come to Madame Gazel's defense in a most spectacular fashion. Even if they don't approve of it, they do seem to respect it.
Still, some part of this stranger remains unconvinced, which makes sense. Your lie was absolutely preposterous.
She's not wrong. You can feel how red your cheeks are.
You can't even remember when the conversation stopped, but both of your wrists are in Madame Gazel's hands, and her lips are drifting so close to yours.
(You have gained some favor with Madame Gazel)
"Good girl."
The rest of the evening is a blur. You're not even sure if you did anything else at the party before you headed home. You spend a few hours trying to peice the events together in your journal.

(You have gained quite a bit of peril)
(You have gained quite a bit of credibility)

Words of purest venom issue forth from your mouth, with such speed and violence that you don't even remember what you said. What you do remember, is the looks on the faces of everyone who heard you say it.
Hurtling from room to room, you come upon her, merrily talking with other guests as if nothing had ever happened. As if she was innocent.
You can't hear anything other than your own breathing and the blood pumping in your ears. The anger is so overwhelming that it's become intoxicating.
Realizing that you've already drawn your fair share of suspicion, the two of you eventually part ways. If nothing else, this has ensured that you've had a lovely evening.
It's not a good feeling.
"You know that's not what I meant."

Taking the time to lock the door this time, the two of you resume your same positions as before, and spend some more time together, whispering meaningless nothings and drawing ever closer. The time slips away from the both of you.
(You have lost a little credibility)
(You have gained quite a bit of favor with Madame Gazel)
"I must admit that I never expected you to be the one to defending me, Yvette. In fact, I never really expected anyone to defend me at all."
(You have gained some peril)
With that she leaves, and tries to slam the door on her way out. Unfortunately for her, the door gets caught on the carpet and just lazily drifts shut.
"This isn't over." She sneers at you both. "You people can't evade the eyes of society forever."
"But you're free to leave at any time."
"You are at least partly correct." Honorade chimes in. "I too am absolutely disgusted."
"W-well, this is disgusting. In fact, both of you are." The interloper replies with with venom, but far quieter than she intended. The lack of volume seems to rob her of the intended gravitas.
"Well, that certainly got my heart racing." Madame Gazel giggles.
After a few moments, the two of you finally exhale in unison.
The suspicious woman leaves, glancing back at the two of you one last time before she disappears from your sight.
"I suppose that's reasonable." She says, with a strange sense of disappointment about her.
Outwardly she looks calm, but she's squeezing your hand so hard that your fingers are starting to tingle.
Unable to stand this indignity anymore, you stand up in a whirl of finery and fury. You rush out the door to find this interloper and tell her exactly what you think of her disgust.

Alone, you just sit in the room by yourself for a while. You lose track of time as you relive every detail of what just transpired, over and over again. You can't help it. All you can do it relive the moments, picking apart the flaws of every exchange.
You glance around the room. There's nothing here except a low fire, and a sense of heartache.
(You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel... Don't worry, it's not really your fault.)
With that, Honorade leaves, and you are alone.
Suddenly, she stands up, the shine of tears just starting to well up in her eyes. "I'm sorry Yvette... I just need to.. I just-"
"I know I said that I was in a great mood before, but this is... that was..." She trails off, never completing the sentence. She doesn't need to.
With that, this person leaves as suddenly as they arrived. Yet, the pall they cast over the room remains. Madame Gazel sighs, and stares at the ceiling.
"Good... I thought as much."
This interloper seems surprised, yet also smugly satisfied. Like weilding this power is what fulfills her.
The two of you sit together in stony silence. Even the crackling of the fire seems muted.
She sneers at you both. "You disgusting people can't evade the eyes of society forever."

(You have lost some credibility)
(You have gained some peril)
Madame Gazel stands up her chair, still holding onto one of your hands. "It's true! My dear friend here is so clumsy. I just have no idea what she'd do without me."
"Oh don't bother with those preposterous lies."

She turns around the canvas and you see yourself. 

The image is surprising, but in an interesting way. You aren't unattractive by any stretch of the imagination, but like most you often gloss over the details of your own features, preferring the image you see in your head. You almost want to disagree with the painting but you know it's correct.

She turns around the canvas and you see your future.

"Alright, you're doing your part just fine. It's time for me to do mine!"

After spending an hour chatting and looking at your figure sketched out on the canvas, you decide to head home. Out in the street, your footsteps feel lighter, the world seems brighter, and more in focus.

When you finally break for the day, Elisabeth takes off her canvas apron, makes some tea, and brings out a few small pastries while you get dressed.

"It's trying. Harsh consequences, but I see the possibility of great rewards."

"It's not 'winning him back', because I don't think he ever stopped loving me."
